description:
BIG PORTIONS. WOW. 
Super quesadilla was not what I expected but still very cheesy and delicious. My boyfriend loved his beef fajitas. 
Came here during the week for lunch and really appreciated the salsa bar plus chips while waiting for food! 
Fast forward a week later and coming home from a backpacking trip. This was the first place that we ate after spending the weekend eating banana chips and peanut butter sandwiches. 
Really hits the spot every time- although it seems a little excessive in price. Given the portions though I would still recommend.
author: Carly A.

description:
After getting some stellar recommendations from friends and strangers, I decided to head over to Taqueria Guadalajara for my first tacos in San Francisco. 

Located in the Mission District between Folsom Street and Shotwell Street, this fun taqueria might as well became one of my favorite food joints. We ordered some Tripas, Pastor, Lengua, and Cabeza to share - and I obviously grabbed a Modelo Negra to wash it all down. 

The food is very affordable and served quickly after you place an order, and there is a variety of selections that you wouldn't easily find in NY taquerias. (That being said, if you are into special cuts of meat, I would highly recommend trying out their Tripas!) Also, dare I mention there is an open salsa bar with excellent condiments to go along with your food?

I can happily say every single bite was excellent and succulent, and I am excited to return to Taqueria Guadalajara for my Mexican fix in the near future.
author: Ji-Sub J.

description:
Late night eats are necessary when you're trying to stay up past midnight. And all those stiff gin cocktails from White Chapel got me craving for some MMMeaty carnitas!

That's exactly what I got: 2 carnitas tacos with the basic onion, salsa, cilantro toppings. The pork had that nice crunch to it and seasoned just right! Our friends tried the cabeza and shrimp tacos, and even in their drunken state, reported that the shrimp was superior than the cabeza in preparation. 

Chips aren't the best and they charge 80 cents per order! :( They do have a salsa bar, so feel free to grab unlimited salsas, but it turns me off that it wasn't kept clean. Granted it's past midnight and there were a barrage of noisy drunks all at once, I hope that's not the case all the time, as it ruins the tranquil Mexican murals on the walls.
author: Janice C.

description: This taqueria joint nestled in the heart of the Mission district of SF is authentic and real as it gets.  In particular are their burritos....wow,; huge, delicious , and satisfying.  Even though we were stuffed,  the place is conducive to chilling, chatting, and munching on chips and salsa.  Before you know it, another hour had gone by...btw. ...we made sure peeps weren't waiting for our table or chairs.
author: Mabe S.

description:
Cute place, cheap beer (2 domestic options, 2 Mexican options).

Hubs ordered a wet shrimp burrito which was freakin huge. Be aware shrimp is an additional $7.

Friendly service :)

We came here on a Saturday afternoon and it was pretty empty. There's a ton of seating and it seems like it would work with larger parties.
author: Sarah L.

description:
Came here on a Tuesday night for some tacos. I ordered the asada taco and a chicken taco. I wish I would have gone with the super taco that comes with sour cream. The tacos were just ok in my opinion. The soft shell almost felt a little flimsy. The meat was pretty good. Salsa was pretty spicy. 

Service was quick and the ambiance was pretty typical for a taqueria in the mission.
author: Taylor F.

description:
I wonder if this place is related to Taqueria Guadalajara in San Leandro?

Nevertheless, this place gets the award for best murals/interior decoration of all the Mission Taquerias. I'm a fan of murals in Taquerias so that was nice to see. 

A friendly woman took my order of a Carnitas taco. I waited patiently and out came a solid Carnitas taco. I typically dont' go for Carnitas taco's because so many places do them "wrong" in my eyes but this place is pretty solid.

The world needs a San Francisco Taco ranking...so I'm here to provide my humble list/rankings. 

Ranking explained:  #1 (listed at the top) is my favorite/ #?  (listed at the bottom) is my least favorite. 

When I look at reviews sometimes just want to know where to go or how a user compares one venue against another to see if we have similar tastes. If you're curious, I have rankings for Boba, Bakeries and Ramen , Chicken and Waffles as well (random right?)  Follow my profile to see my most recent reviews.  I hope I can be helpful since so many Yelpers have helped me discover new places.  

Rod's SF Taco Rankings:

10 Taqueria Los Mayas
author: Rod M.

description:
Like most taquerias in the Mission, it really depends on what you get. Their chorizo tacos, pollo asado (in any form), and shrimp burrito are all really, really good. But, their carne asada is thin and tough, chips are mediocre, and salsa is fine, but unremarkable.

But, seriously, they've got the best pollo asado or shrimp burritos in the Mission.
author: Ryan W.

description:
Yummy vegetarian taco. The taco could use a little more cheese. It was a little under $4.

The salsa bar has some spicy salsas! The red tomato salsa was tasty and spicy. 

The complementary chips are nice too, maybe a little too salty. I would come here for a taco again. 

_________

Update. I just ordered the veggie burrito. It was solid. Also, again, the red tomato salsa, is soo good. I would love to know what spices are in there, but there's green onion and it's on point in the salsa.

I don't think the chips are too salty anymore. They have a good crisp.
author: Shruti D.

description:
Their carnitas are amazing! Crispy and tender, ugh just perfect for my tacos. 

I like how they have a salsa bar, and I always enjoy eating the pickled carrots, which was actually pretty spicy to me.

My friend's plate was humongous, and the plate definitely could had fed the both of us. 

I also got the asada taco, and I was a little disappointed at how dry it was. The meat was dry, and it could have used some more sauce and I poured some pico de gallo from the salsa bar on top. If I come next time, I will just get the carnitas and maybe try the shrimp!

The interior feels very colorful and home-y!
author: Tiffany H.

description:
Had the super nacho with asada and was really disappointed. The asada didn't taste flavored and some pieces were chewy so I had to spit it out. A lot of the chips were embedded and too soft to hold and eat so I used a fork to pick through to grab some meat pieces and a chunk of melted beans and chips.

Reminder to self to move past and go to my favorite local Mexican place instead.
author: Summer S.

description:
Tried the asada and lengua burrito and pollo (they ran out of chorizo) burrito. 

Both were good but not mind blowing. They were very big though and filling. Asada was probably a touch dry but lengua was nice and tender. Pollo burrito was very tasty. 

Ordered takeout via Postmates and it came up to $20 (incl tax) plus another $4+ for Postmates service fee and $5.99 delivery fee. Next time I'll call to order to save on all these extra fees and would rather give it directly to the small business owner. What a rip off by Postmates.
author: Carmen P.

description:
Step one upon arriving to San Francisco: Go to the Mission. 

Step two: Find tacos. 

I always like to ask people, "If you could eat one type of cuisine for the rest of your life, what would it be?" For me, the answer is hands down Mexican. Taqueria Guadalajara proves why.

On a recent lunch outing, my group opted to try a new spot for Mexican in lieu of another tried and true joint. I was a bit hangry and decided to go with a tostada topped with carne asada and a solitary taco with carnitas, after reading the rave reviews. Chips and salsa is free (as it should ALWAYS be) and overall, it's pretty darn cheap. The food came out fast and hot. I really have no complaints about either of my dishes and could see why that juicy carnitas meat gets people excited! The tostada was LOADED with meat, beans and veggies. Just how I like it!

I'd be remiss to not mention the salsa bar... They have about five different salsas ranging in various levels of spice. My fave was the salsa verde. I probably could've ate that with chips all day long. 

It's a no frills spot with plenty of seating and they were nice enough to let us push some tables together and really make ourselves at home.

I left practically having to be rolled out after chowing down here. It's probably my favorite taco spot thus far in the Mission!
author: Cassie P.

description:
Made our way to the Mission for some tacos. This spot ain't fancy - you have the homemade, handmade vibes going on here. I was pretty pumped to see reggaeton videos playing on the tv in the restaurant, made me feel right at home and ready for some delicious food!

You've got your choice of plenty of meats to top your tacos, tostadas or burritos. They also have entree plates.

I went with a Super Baby Burrito. When I noticed this option had a "baby size" I was immediately frightened by how large the regular would be. The Baby size was just right. Filled with super tender carnitas, avocado, cheese, sour cream and beans - it was everything I hoped for in a burrito.

All orders come with house made chips, which I dunked into various spicy sauces from their salsa bar. Damn, this spot has so so many sauces to choose from. This saucy lady was super pleased with them - especially the pickled shredded carrots and onions. Spicy, tangy, and exactly what you'd want when you're obsessed with fermented foods.

Would definitely return for the tacos - as the ones I spied on my neighbors plates looked delightful. Again this place offers zero frills, but tons of flavor!
author: Diandra L.

description:
I don't normally write reviews. 

But this is about the 5th time I have gone to this place for their super shrimp burrito, and it never disappoints.

Think of a calm day on a beach in Hawaii. Or it can even be at your local beach if you've never been there. I'm not much into surfing, but the only way I can describe this burrito is a fresh killer wave bursting with flavor. The shrimp provides your mouth with a sweet and savory aroma, while the perfect combination of garlic, butter, bell peppers, and rice compliment the shrimp in perfect harmony. It is like riding a big wave and experiencing that high when you hit the big one. Now the orange habanero sauce is to die for. If you aren't into spicy I would just recommend a tiny bit, because IT IS HOT. The habanero sauce provides that twist of citrus and spicy pepper flavor that hits you like a coming hurricane at the beach. Your mouth will be exploding with so many flavors the shrimp will magically come to life and dance around you in a summer blowout. Kumbaya my lord all day.

They give you a very generous portion of shrimp, and it's always perfectly cooked so it's just the right amount of chew and snap. The price is a bit high ($13.10 advertised and $14+ with tax), but that's for the super which comes with cheese, sour cream, and avocado. If you're not a fan of avocado you can get the regular, but if you want to dive into the habanero sauce I would recommend, because the avocado gives a nice creamy balance to the hot citrusy explosion of the shrimp+ sauce combo.

This place is definitely my go to spot for shrimp burritos, and I will be returning.
author: Galen L.

description: I use to love the super shrimp quesadilla.... the shrimp was big and fresh. The veggie and salsa were so good. I went to get one today...shrimp was smaller and doesnt taste fresh. Even the avocado portion shrink but the price went up. Very disappointed!
author: anita s.

description: Good spot for a carnitas super burrito if you want to avoid all the tourists and bro's at La Taqueria. It was a very good burrito. The chips aren't that great (but somehow they were all eaten!) Bottled Mexican beers are $5, which seems steep. It was quiet on a Sunday afternoon; no problem sitting for a long time with a book.
author: J E.

description: What a gem! This is my favorite spots for a taco fix in the mission! This place opens late and had great friendly service. Their chicken tacos are delicious and flavorful. Definitely get the super tacos because it comes with delicious chicken toppings like cheese and avocado. There's a lot of salsa selections to choose from but my favorite is the green sauce. My boyfriend also enjoyed the carnitas and carne asada tacos.
author: Jacqui C.

description:
Low key eatery delivering amazing food.

Why are the chips so good? I try to eat healthy and then I come here and they serve me addicting chips. I even posed the question out loud because I was shocked by how good the tortilla chips are. Whatever it is, they have found the secret.

I went with the shrimp tacos and they were superb. The shrimp was plump and flavorful. I made the mistake of trying some of the sauces and one was kick yo mamma spicy. I legit had to chug water after taste testing that salsa. If you are a spice wuss like me, you'll want to stay away.

There were a ton of seats, but we came at a random off time between lunch and dinner. I would definitely recommend this place to anyone looking for some good Mexican food.
author: Christina G.

description:
After some Paint Nite action, an artist can get hungry so I ventured in search of much needed tacos in the Mission District. 

Me and two others ended up here and I got the lengua and carne asada tacos.  The lengua was the better of the two and once you get pass that you're eating a tongue, it becomes acceptably amazing. Tender and didn't reek of any terrible after taste. Carne asada was lacking flavor but they probably gave us some before closing portion. 
Both were decent but probably not up to my expectations considering all the other options around us.  My friend got an order of the carne asada fries and it didn't look that great. One thing I wish more places would do is use the skinny or thinner cut fries. That way it doesn't end up as mashed potatoes once all the juices and sauces flow together. Just my two cents.

I definitely prefer their spot in Excelsior. This assumes it's the same ownership and I think it is because their menus are very similar. If you do go here, get the super shrimp quesadilla for sure!
author: Quoc N.

description:
Do you know how hard it is to find a FAT veggie burrito, particularly when you order it sin queso, sin guacamole? Damn hard, that's how. They're always skinny and understuffed, as if those assembling don't think to fill the vacancies left by omitted ingredients with extra rice & beans. But Guadalajara has done it; they made the burrito of my dreams--light on lettuce and so plump it was fixing to pop. And I ate the whole thing, barely stopping to breathe. 

I was pleased with their salsa bar as well. Loved the fresh pico. The chips were unremarkable but fresh, and I was too busy inhaling my burrito to notice them anyway.

Some people have mentioned rude service, but I didn't have a problem in that regard. I arrived at about 2AM, so maybe there were different employees working, but the girl at the counter was nice and my food arrived in a timely fashion. 

My complaints are negligible: the restaurant was too cold to eat in comfortably; please turn on the heater. And apparently the bathroom was a disaster zone, but I didn't see it firsthand. 

In any case, I will definitely be returning.
author: Ellery D.

description:
I can't quit this little mexican place in the outer mission, it's open late and always buzzing. There's a sister location on 24th street, but some of us have loyalty to the OG.

First things first, best salsa bar in SF:
-pico
-red salsa
-salsa verde (2 types)
-carrot slaw
-nopales salad
-escabeche (2 types)
-limes
-radishes
-super super hot habenero sauce

As far as food options - chorizo quesadilla is loaded with meat/cheese/sour cream and is more than big enough for a meal. The burrito is good too, but watch out for the rice. We got the nachos once, and I think we gained 5 lbs, but it was a happy weight gain.
author: Billy D.

description:
There's so much great Mexican food in SF! It's become a bit of a tradition that whenever I am in SF I have tacos/Mexican for my first meal in town.

Off the plane, refreshed at the hotel, and starving...I met up with a few of my favorite people. The place isn't huge, but it's a decent size. We snagged 4 tables and went ham on a bunch of different things.

I got a torta. It's massive and I couldn't finish it. I offered everyone at the table some bites - and they were all about that base. Got it with steak and it comes stacked with viggies, cheese crema and other goodies.

The salsas go from oh, that's a nice kick to holy shit I just tongue kissed the Devil. My counterpart from Tampa, Christina G, tried to tango with the Devil...and lost. I think I legit saw smoke come out of her mouth.

Luckily we cooled down with some horchatta. The horchatta was delicious. If you haven't had it it's a traditional Mexican rice drink. It's creamy and has cinnamon. It's great to cool off your mouth if you so should need to. Or you know, chug it cause it's simply delicious.
author: Blue A.

description:
Very affordable and large shrimp burrito! 

Got a burrito to go, and it comes with tortilla chips. You can serve yourself salsas--the orange one is HOT. The place isn't entirely beautiful in terms of atmosphere, and the floors are definitely not a place to do the 5-second-rule if you drop something...but it's a solid taqueria. 

It's a great spot if you don't want to wait in line at either La Taq's. I came here to get a quick dinner before a house party, and we ended up waiting a while. A solid 15 minutes because the dinner rush started a bit early. They were definitely understaffed with two ladies in the front, and I could only see a cook in the back.

Either way, food is SOLID. Shrimp is HUGE. Will definitely be back.
author: Jodi H.

description:
Seems fitting that the first thing I eat when I land in California is a burrito. 

Right when we dropped off our bags at the hotel, my colleagues suggested going to get some grub. I tagged along not really sure where we were going but was happy to find out we were going to be eating Mexican. Vancouver doesn't have the most authentic Mexican cuisine, so whenever I go down the States I always try to eat as much Mexican food as I can. 

We pulled up to Taqueria Guadalajara to see that this place is not high end whatsoever. But I was completely okay with that. From the looks of the dishes that were coming out of the kitchen, this place screamed "authentic" and my Mexican-loving belly was more than excited. There are plenty of options ranging from tacos, burritos, tostadas, and quesadillas - all with a variety of meats, seafood, and veggies. 

I ordered the veggie burrito with extra hot sauce, unknowing that there was a "baby burrito" option. When I heard that, I was a little nervous to see how big mine would be. It was huge. But, I was a fan. I wasn't able to get a photo of it because I ended up just digging in right away and was totally consumed by the deliciousness. I ate as much as I could and eventually gave up when there was about a 1/4 left. 

I did not leave disappointed. The food was fresh, filling, and exactly what I wanted. Next time I come back, I'm switching things up and trying the tacos and tostadas. Mmm, mmm, mmm!
author: Issabelle F.

description: We wanted a snack after dinner and drinks and so popped in for a taco or two each. I tried the lengua, and it was a large taco filled with delicious and soft beef tongue. I'd like to come back and try more items.
author: James K.

description: This place i great! The service was amazing and the tacos were as authentic as I remember them when I was in Guadalajara. Highly recommend this place! Can't wait to go again!
author: Cindy Z.

description:
This place is fire.  Fresh, authentic, awesome. New favorite for sure!!!

Tried the carne Asada burrito and it was incredible. 

Also the pastor is some of the best I've had. 

If you don't like this place something is wrong with you.
author: Mikey S.

description:
Interior design is amazing! Got the super burrito with al pastor, loved it. Also came with free chips, yay! Friends got the vegetarian super burrito and loved it as well. Salsa bar available. Staff was really friendly which made the experience all the better. Service was a tad slow due to limited workers today but I wasn't in a rush and dis not mind at all. Could tell they were working super hard and did not slack at all, very efficient.

Metered street parking, make sure you know exactly how much time you have on the meter because SF really enforces parking. Meter maids are always circling around checking.
author: Wendy T.

description:
there are so many great Taquerias in the Mission.
it's true that there are better burritos in the vicinity but Taqueria Guadalajara is the place where you will get good size burritos, great service and great topping bar.
the place is never get too crowded, always good times.
author: Rudy H.

description:
During my recent Mission district taqueria crawl, which isn't over yet and was inspired by my desire to sample as many different veggie tacos - the staple of my livin'-in-San-Francisco-on-a-budget diet, I dropped by Taqueria Guadalajara when one of the more popular spots in the barrio had a line out the door (El Farolito or La Taqueria). Although the place isn't fancy, the food is good, the service is friendly, and the price is right.

I've been back a second time and can vouch for their $3.36 veggie taco. If you're at all familiar with other taquerias in the area, Guadalajara's version reminded me of what you'd find at Cancún or Farolito.
author: Beau W.

description:
I love the Guadalajara in the outer mission... but I'm sorry I can't think likewise about this particular location. 

I should've saw it coming when I was getting salsa from the salsa bar because the salsa was not fresh at all & the salsa verde was super watered down/thin consistency? The pico de gallo also looked super dull.
Sad Sad because the outer mission location has really good salsa Verde and you can see chunks of avocado when scooping. 

I got the shrimp burrito, which was mediocre and my bf got the el pasto burrito which gave him FOOD POISONING! It led to vomiting and runs to the bathroom all day the next day...
I'm guessing the pork was NOT fresh, since I wasn't contaminated by the shrimp burrito.

But anyways, it was pretty bad and I will never be returning to this location ever again. I recommend going down the block to El Farlito on 24th street.
author: Leilani Y.

description: It looks like the owner is very rude at this place. my kids were trying to get a container to take their food to go. They grabbed a container themselves because they was no one around and she noticed and came To take the containers and said that those were not to be used for quesadillas. She came and took their food out of the container and put it in a bag, without asking if she can touch our food. She should not be running a business.
author: Maria P.

description:
I go here sometimes to mix it up from the El Farolito runs and it is right down the street from there too.

They take credit cards which is a plus! And their food is just as tasty! I love that there isn't a huge line every time I go there and it isn't jammed packed with drunk belligerent people. It is more low key and spacious. They are on the pricier side as their one suggested dish (Shrimp quesadilla) is about $8. It is good though!!! The food comes out very fast and they have a ton of sauces to choose from. Portion wise it is just right and the meat isn't dry.

Customer service wise, not really there (as expected) but it would be nice if they asked if you wanted a bag with your to-go order before charging you for one...not a huge deal but just expect your only interaction with them to be at the counter.

FYI they actually close MUCH later than 1AM as listed on Yelp...I went around 3AM and they were still open. I believe the person on the phone said they were open until 5AM!!!!
author: Allison S.

description: The costumer service is friendly, but the food is not the best. I would not recommend the pastor meat and definitely look for something else. Again, nothing wrong with the people, the food is the issue. It's just not good.
author: Diana E.

description: Found this place while walking down 24 street on a Friday night.  Ordered a carne asada baby super burrito and a Mexican coke. The food tasted fine and staff seemed efficient.  Nice they give you chips and salsa while you wait - but it was nothing to write home about.  My burrito was average.  Nothing wrong with it - but couldn't find anything that made it stand out either. The place is worth a try but not going to change your life.
author: Robert C.

description: Holy hell I'm blown away by how great this place is! I never write reviews but this place deserves a shout out. I got the carnitas burrito and chorizo nachos - both meats were perfectly cooked, great flavor. And they have an amazing spicy salsa. Fresh avocado. Had the food delivered through postmates - it was excellent and all special instructions were followed. This place is going to be my new go-to taqueria. For real.
author: Codi L.

description:
Awesome local place that we stumbled upon, we were craving Mexican food. It's a quiet part of the street and when we walked in there was nobody inside. We decided to try it out the menu was pretty typical and it had everything you'd expect. It just looked fairly normal inside your typical mom and pop looking shop.

The food was above average for sure though, which we weren't surprised at all because it looked like it had a lot of potential! I had the chicken enchiladas which as good as it gets! The beans, rice and enchiladas were pretty fresh and tasted like they were just made and baked then. It was also a good filling portion and was extremely satisfying!
author: Christopher L.

description:
I love this place! 2 locations in SF!  My favorite order is the; Super Baby Burrito, with spinach wrap, lite rice, avocado slices, black beans & steak! Fresh spicy salsa, green hot sauce and lime wedges! Yum!  They close late, late night, too!

Super Nachos are great too!
author: Jimmy N.

description: This place has tasty small intestine tacos and tasty habanero hot sauce (the orange one). Their lengua + carne asada tacos were good too. Tacos are around $3.50 each, which is not affordable in my opinion, but they give free chips and salsa! There were many different choices for free sauce, but I only liked their habanero hot sauce.
author: Jenn H.

description:
Came here because the line at El Farolito was way too long and it was way too cold to be standing outside.

I still prefer El Farolito but this is a great second place to hit up when you want a good burrito.
author: Jessica S.

description:
We stopped in here after a long drive.

I ordered the guacamole to go - for $5.00.

When it arrived - I thought that perhaps they had mistakenly given me salsa - but no - that's the way Taqueria Guadalajara serves up their guacamole. It was mostly all onions, was extremely watery, and had very little avocado within it.  I spied maybe two and half chunks of avocado in the whole cup. I understand that different spots make their guacamole differently  - but with such a poor showing of avocado - I felt that the price-tag was way too high - when you are essentially paying for onion heavy salsa. 

My dining partner's burrito looked hearty and nourishing - but I will be skipping Taqueria Guadalajara for my guacamole fix.

Trust.
author: Jessica T.

description:
We rolled in here about 45 min before closing and it's dead quiet, just us and one other guy. Street parking is deserted...it looks slightly more expensive than other places...so I'm initially skeptical. 

Then I got my food and started eating and ZOMG 5 stars! 

In a neighborhood like the mission it can be hard to stand out as a Mexican joint. How does this place do it? Outstanding shrimp (available in burritos etc), mind blowing chorizo, and above average salsas. I got half and half shrimp chorizo nachos and OH MAN was that the right call, even if the $12 price tag puts it solidly above some other (non-be-shrimp-tacled) places. 

Will come back any time, and it can be nice to have the quiet atmosphere over the chaos that is el farolito. Watch out for the habanero salsa, it's rough. I prefer the jalapeño one. 

Now if they'd only price that horchata more cheaply...
author: Chris S.

description:
Strictly found this place by hearing that the Mission is the place to get tacos and Yelp. The ambiance is exactly what I would hope for when searching for great tacos. Soccer was on in Spanish, and they didn't win any beautification awards from Home and Garden. They had a few beer choices. And you got some chips, salsa, and guac with your meal. The chips were decent at best. But the dips were pretty good.

I got the steak, shrimp, pork, and chorizo tacos. All were really good. But the chorizo stuck out well above the others. And even though it would typically be favorite of mine, the steak was my least favorite. But you could tell the ingredients in each were fresh and delicious. I also had a bite of my dinner companions beef tongue. Something I have had before... but not often. And this was by far the best I have eaten.

If you are looking for great authentic tacos and a cold beer, this is a great stop for you!
author: Will B.

description:
Came in here with no idea what to expect other than the fact that we could get some serious taco's inside. Order at the counter from the no frills menu and make your choice between tacos, a burrito, or a few other entrees. The have a "super" options which adds cheese and stuff for an up charge. The place is small but we found a table after hitting the salsa bar and managed to steal a chair from another group.

There's a dingy convenience store vibe going on and a TV that was blasting a muy importante fútbol game. The offer a few soft drinks and a few beers to choose from too. I started with the free chips. I can't say much because they're free, but they weren't made in house and were pretty terrible. The salsa on the other hand was great. You could have given me cardboard (chips were a similar equivalent) and I would have been just as happy to use it as a vehicle to get the salsa in my face.

The tacos were the reason I was here and they didn't disappoint. The carnitas was as good as everyone else says so definitely add it to your list. The surprise taco was the lengua. I had never had beef tounge, but was willing to give it a shot. The meat was so tender and delicious that it was a close runner up for first place on my plate. The pollo was good, but didn't hold a candle to the others. Give this taco shop a shot on your next mission stop!
author: Scotty C.

description: This place is seriously the best Mexican food spot I've been to outside of LA! They're not greedy with their meat or avocado! The asada is top notch! Also try the shrimp at this place you will love it! Isn't expensive at all compared to all the hipster places surrounding it! Great service over all!
author: Frazer V.

description: I ordered veggie nachos to go. I got home, made myself comfortable and then I opened the container to see beef EVERYWHERE. I'm a vegetarian so I called them up to see if they could do something about it. Nobody picked up. It's wasn't even busy when I ordered so why did they put beef in veggie nachos?
author: Guramrit K.

description:
Food quality = meh.
Service = sucks (except for one woman who is never there, or I never seem to catch - she's amazing). 

Adriana hates me, it seems. I could happily spend the rest of my life eating rice and beans and, more often than not, I get SERIOUS cravings for my r&b + some pineapple or strawberry Jarritos. Such as last night. And never again will I come here. 

My order is never right, and it couldn't be any more simple. Last night I ordered rice and WHOLE beans, a pineapple jarritos, and I asked for 2 FLOUR quesadillas for my roomie (yuck, I only love corn). We got rice, refried beans, and corn tortilla quesadillas, and no soda. 1 our of 4 is better than zero, but...SERIOUSLY? She obviously hates me. Not to mention she acts like it would kill her if she were to smile. And there were chunks of flesh in my refried beans (which is why I order whole beans - I have zero desire to eat animals). 

Never again, Guadalajara (and I live across the street and am lazy AF when I want my rice and beans). I will hoof my rear elsewhere from now on, where simple items are prepared with care and served with a smile. Good luck with the attitude and salsa bar that smells like dirty bleach.
author: Christy M.

description: First time here, delicious burritos and outstanding service! Great flavors. I grabbed a veggie super burrito and my husband a pastor burrito. The onions in the pastor - stellar touch. Oh, and they are gigantic!
author: Kyra W.

description: Seriously amazing tacos, some of the best that I have ever had. I had a shrimp taco and a carnitas taco and both were pretty bomb. My favorite part is that they didn't skimp out on the meat on either taco. The shrimp one had 5 juicy and pretty large shrimp and the flavor was awesome. I had two tacos but if I was hungrier three would have been the perfect number.
author: Andrea M.

description: No frills but the best burrito I have ever had. My husband and I have been back so many times but I always get the same thing- super burrito with pollo asado. Everything that goes into it is super flavorful plus they have a great salsa bar on the side! Great selection of Mexican beers too. This Guadalajara location is one of many reasons to love the Calle 24 district of the mission. Mexicali culture is delicious, welcoming, and beautiful.
author: Nora C. E.

description:
A catalog of my Taqueria Guadalajara inner dialogue::

*  It's a mess in here.  Tables aren't cleared.  It smells unpleasant.  If I weren't getting a to-go order I'd not stay.

*  A regular Carne Asada burrito is $7.50?  When did that happen?  

*  Sketchy looking salsa bar.  I hope it's safe.  (This is before I even see Gabriela W's fitting comment, "busted a** salsa bar, like the kind that makes you think of hepatitis A").

*  Chips in my bag?  Nice.  I love chips.

That's when my inner dialogue morphed into something else entirely:

Two bites into the first tortilla chip I realize it's the worst tortilla chip I've ever encountered.  I spit it out and reach for the burrito. 

In my first bite of burrito I encounter a chewy, gristly, inedible slice of carne asada.  I spit it out and hope for better luck with bite number two.

Bite number two yields the exact same results.  I spit again.

I've now spent more time spitting than consuming.  

The burrito appears to have no salsa (despite what the menu said).  It's fatty, chewy, awful meat, with pinto beans, and rice.  

Did I mention that I was starving, trying to eat while driving and searching for a parking space?  

I reach for some (hep A) salsa to give the crap burrito some flavor.  The salsa container unleashes.  I'm covered in the stuff.  It's on my coat, my car seat, my shirt, my jeans.  Dinner as metaphor.

I park.  Bag up my spit sack and deposit it in the nearest trashcan.  

Taqueria Guadalajara, for those times when you'd rather spit than swallow.
author: Tracey A.

description:
FIRST OF ALL, I don't know what the hell a Mission-style burrito is lmfao. It's an atrocity tbh. I'm pretty sure the burrito gods have been rolling over in their graves since this has been made. I don't want more rice in my burrito. I don't want more flexible tortilla. THAT'S CALLED CHIPOTLE~ OMGGG

Okay, so now that I've established how foolish I think this is (agree to disagree, Mission burrito fans), this place is actually pretty good. Got their breakfast burrito which was nothing super mind-blowing but still pretty bomb and super filling due to superflex-mission-tortilla.

They have bomb avocado salsa too and solid tortilla chips. But sorry SF compatriots, this real ain't better than LA.
author: Brian W.

description:
My mom was born in Guadalajara. She cooks the legit s***. Always has, so my palate is well-trained. 

I was expecting this taqueria to throw down, be my surrogate SF mama, transport me to a magical place.

Denied. 

Busted a** salsa bar, like the kind that makes you think of hepatitis A.

The tostadas and enchiladas were decent. That's it. Minus ten points for using lard to make their retried beans. They packed my tostadas in foil. Another minus ten points. 

I'm sticking to El Farolito and El Toro.
author: Gabriela W.

description: Horrible service. Came in Thursday around 6pm cashier lady was extremely rude. After rushing my order and having to repeat it twice she still got it wrong. When I tried to get it fixed she  got verbal with me. Very unprofessional, will never be back here.
author: Jose H.

description:
Their food's OK-- it's mostly food-service ingredients, nothing very fresh or especially tasty. It's really cheap. Fresh OJ's nice.

Description of their decor:  they've decorated their window with an employment sign that lets us all know that they explicitly and publically discriminate against women in hiring. A sign Taqueria Guadalajara posted in their window says they're hiring for a janitor, who must be a man. I asked inside why the janitor must be a man, and they said because the job is hard. I said it's not fair to prevent women from getting jobs they can do just because they're women, and besides being unfair sexual discrimination in hiring is not legal. They said they'd talk about it. The sign is still in the window, unchanged, several days later.
author: Janet S.

description: Friend and I found small piece of meat after ordering nachos with no meat. We're vegan.
author: Megan I.

description:
To be honest, after a while all the taquerias in the Mission blur together in a drunken haze. This isn't the best, but points for the open salsa bar, the habanero sauce (it's SPICY ), the smiling service, and the lack of the Farolito lines. 

My super lengua quesadilla was solid, if a little soggy. 


I have yet to try the legendary carnitas, so maybe I'll need to bump up a few stars once I do.
author: Lan T.

description: I had a chicken quesadilla, and I loved the way they cooked the chicken! It was super tasty and not greasy like in other places. They have a lot of seating and nice murals.
author: Francesca M.

description:
Guadalajara may, in all honesty, may have the most underrated burrito in the city.  I sort of hope that nobody finds out about it because I prefer not to wait in line, but I guess i'll stop being selfish.  If you don't believe me, try the Carnitas.  Quality is consistent from visit to visit.

The Habanero salsa is bomb.  And by that, I mean it literally blows up in your mouth.  Disconcerting, but I really appreciate the citrus twang.

House chips are comparable to Farolito, but again -- the wait is not.
author: Garret H.

description: Great place to end the night! We went bar hopping in the Mission. I had some carnitas tacos to end the night. They were amazing! But I was drunk so grains of salt...
author: Thomas J.

description:
We came here on a Friday night for a quick dinner. Though not a gold standard, the tacos are still pretty good. I have a taste for salt, so I needed to sprinkle some on mine. Their marinated pork (al pastor) are juicy and tasty. I think the pollo and asada are lacking a little. Beef was kind of dry. The corn tortillas are fresh and everything came out piping hot. 

I really like their salsa bar. They've got a lot more choice than most of the Taquerias, including picked carrot, multiple types of pickled jalapenos and one with sauteed onions. Salas are hot!

Standard place and still great.
author: Priti K.

description: Absolutely nothing to brag about or be proud of this place has ok service and the food is over priced for the lack of taste it has. Also you don't get limes or lemons with tacos the decorations inside are nice though.
author: Based O.

description:
Probably one of my favorite Taquerias in the Mission. Reasonably priced, delicious food, good portion sizes. I prefer to dine in because then I don't have to tote home every salsa at their salsa bar in my purse and risk spilling it all over my stuff (because I refuse to buy a 10 cent bag, yea it's like that).

Not really sure what else to say, other than it's delicious and everything is fresh and hot and yummy. I like hot hot hot spicy food, like, so spicy one might shed a tear or have trouble breathing for several minutes. I don't know why I like it or can handle it, stomach of steel perhaps? I usually ask for extra hot sauce in my burrito and extra jalapeños and it's still not hot enough for me, so then I use whatever hot sauce is available (La Victoria with the black label preferably, but Tapatio will do) and then slice up some pickled jalapeños to add to my dish.

Their pink habanero salsa is pretty spicy so I appreciate that, and I like to mix it with the Verde salsa because I think it has better flavor. The habanero is a little on the lemony side, and I've brought it home to use on other foods but it doesn't hold the same effect as it does on a burrito, nachos, or tacos from Guadalajara. 

The restaurant is a tad dirty, just to be up front, but it's quaint feel, muraled walls, and deep straw chairs make for a comfortable and amiable dining experience.
author: Crystal C.

description:
I am liking their burritos and tacos more than the others in the area that are open past midnight. 
Try them if you haven't
author: LuisD M.

description:
I'm leaving a review for the grilled chicken super burrito. I've had it way too many times and it's so amazing and delicious and can never get myself to try anything else here. And I'm like, a big Mexican food fan. And I like the authentic Mexican food, spicy and flavorful. I've tried so many burritos from so many other taquerias in the city, and this one wins it for me. I also love the salsa bar here. Love the roasted jalapeños and avocado and regular salsas. 

Can't speak for all the other food, but the grilled chicken super burrito.....man its the best!!
author: Yara K.

description: Ok let me just say I like the food. It had taste and it was good. I know I was in the mission. But the place could use a little up keep. Try sitting in those chairs. You will sink in them. I didnt have the salsa cause who knows what is in that whole mix. I think places like that should have squeeze bottles.  Other than that its not too bad.
author: Ray R.

description: Booo.  Pale and fermented-tasting salsa fresca, fatty, low density, and bland carnitas burrito, and dry chicken tacos, all at elevated Mission prices.  Avoid and instead wait out the lines at the many better places surrounding this place.
author: Rob P.

description: Another incredible unknown mission burrito. Cheese was excellently melted and the fried carnitas was perfect. Very large size and excellent mix/composition. I almost couldn't finish it. Decor made us feel like we were actually in Guadalajara. Will be back again soon after my burrito tour finishes.
author: Tom F.

description: The horchata was milky. But the burrito was incomparable to el farolito. But there are complementary chips. The burrito was kind of for my taste as well as the green salsa.
author: Fernilla S.

description:
My boyfriend and I discovered this place earlier this week, and already went back for more! It's delicious - truly a hidden gem of the Mission.

You order at the counter and then they bring your food to you. Chips and salsa are free and unlimited, which is a nice way to pass the time while waiting for food. They also have some cool drinks. Aside from the standard sodas and beers, they had some Mexican drinks and sodas that looked enticing (although we just stuck with Coronas).

I ordered the shrimp tacos (I tried Super one time and just the normal shrimp tacos the other time) - both were delicious, very flavorful and the right amount of spicy. Between the two of them, though, I prefer the normal tacos. They had a great salsa and seasoning on the shrimp that was very unique. The Super shrimp tacos had avocado, sour cream, onions/peppers and salsa. Still delicious, but my personal preference was "non-super." I got two tacos both times, which was enough to fill me up with chips and salsa. I think 3 would be a good amount for someone with more of an appetite.

The boyfriend got the steak supreme quesadilla both times. The quesadillas are HUGE, so be warned, but he was up to the challenge. The steak has a great seasoning and they use high quality cheese and tortillas.
author: Sarah L.

description:
Where else in SF can you get a decent veggie burrito (authentic) for less than $6? 

I can't say I'm an expert of Mexican cuisine but I've grown up eating the authentic stuff and eat it regularly and frequently. I think by now I've had enough of it to be able to sort out the good and the bad.

The burrito I had had a good ratio of fillings: beans, rice, lettuce, tomato, sour cream and they just use avocado rather than guacamole which is fine, although I personally prefer guacamole. Flavor was great and everything was distributed well throughout the entire burrito. It's fairly massive so make sure you are hungry before picking one up. 

I still haven't found THE ONE taqueria in the Mission but for now this'll do as one of our go-to's for our frequent burrito habit. A couple of the other Mission favorites that everyone and their mothers seems to love while okay, are overrated.
author: Esther A.

description: Very solid taqueria, nothing extraordinary but holds its own on the mission scene.  Their salsa bar is kinda jank and they're not going to be as fast as Farolito, Pancho Villa or Cancun but their food is legit.  I had a grilled chicken super burrito and it was up there with its peers.
author: Saminda W.

description: I've been here a few times. It is always great food & good service, the females who work here are really sweet. Last time I was here, I ordered the super nachos with pollo asado, they accidentally put the chips on the side, I don't know why, but I didn't complain, I just ate it... it was a good idea because the chips didn't get soggy! I'm going to get my nachos like that all the time now ;)
author: Jane S.

description: Yummy, yum yum shrimp tacos. Much fresher shrimp than any other taqueria. Loud TV and bright garish flourescent lights, but great salsa and a big room to talk and meet with large or small groups.
author: Katharine H.

description:
We came to this taqueria after a late night in the Mission so I wasn't sure if I actually loved the food or if I had just been really hungry.

Hence, I came back a week later and realized that I did love it after all. The place itself isn't ritzy or chic but the food is scrumptious. I was crying the entire time because of how spicy my food was but I like to judge my food based on how many tears it induces.

Con: there were bugs. Not on the food. Or not that I can recall. But I have a terrible memory so perhaps.
author: Tania S.

description: Delicious burritos, reasonably priced and nice atmosphere. Highly recommend when in the Mission!
author: Julia P.

description:
Popped in to grab something to-go.

Got one on the big mission style burritos (chorizo). It was very good and very filling. The habanero salsa was good. It starts a bit fruity and the kick comes a bit later.

I'll definitely be back.
author: Paul D.

description: Terrible food.  Incompetent staff.  They had my last review removed because I didn't focus on how bad the food was, I guess.  Well, it's awful.  How's that?
author: Isaac C.

description:
Repeat after me: El Farolito is not the only Mexican taco place near the 24th Street Bart.

You could go to El Farolito. You could wait in line, you could deal with all the drunk white people coming back from the bars. You could probably even listen to them try and convince their friend that "This is the Best Burrito in all of NorCal, dude" as if limiting the competition to Sacramento and Tahoe somehow makes this impressive. I'm willing to bet these weekend warriors haven't been down to San Jose, not counting that time they missed their Caltrain stop. 

Or you could walk down the street to Taqueria Guadalajara where everyone eating there probably could take a decent shot at pronouncing its name. Get some amazing Carnitas on whatever burrito/taco you order. Consider trying some other meats, get more carnitas instead. Enjoy their huge salsa bar. Marvel at the free chips. Drink the water in cups so clean, they still taste like soap. Be amazed at how little you spent. Sit down in the surprisingly spacious seating area. 

Be happy.
author: Jake B.

description: Let me start by saying I am from San Diego where the  Mexican food reigns supreme. This place is by far the best Mexican "taco shop" in the Mission.  We had the super nachos with asada, which were bomb! Plenty of cheese and real avocado. We also had the lengua and grilled chicken tacos. The chicken was okay, but the lengua was pretty good.   The habanero salsa was not only hot but it was fresh and tasty.
author: Kris Marie D.

description: Fantastic burritos, great chips, super reasonably priced at $8, and no line like papalote. Authentic, true Mexican food.
author: Ben G.

description:
I came here with high expectations and was sorely let down.

I got a carnitas taco and al pastor taco.  I felt that while the carnitas had a pleasant crunch to it, the tacos/meat were under seasoned/salted.  One of the tacos was the original and the other one had the sour cream and avocado.  While the avocado and sour cream were fine additions, it didn't scream authentic to me.  The original taco was drenched in some kind of sauce/salsa that I also felt was unnecessary.  

The woman at the cash register must have been having the worst day of her life because she was not having it.  My friend ordered and gave the woman her card to pay and the women  quoted her the price for the meal.  My friend asked her why it was so high and we found that the woman was charging her for a shrimp taco supreme (she wanted the regular without the peppers).  The woman had not yet charged the card so my friend asked her to please adjust the price/order to what she wanted.  The woman angrily said that could not be done, turned her back to us, marched over to the CC machine, and swiped the card much to our surprise.  My friend said fine its only a few bucks difference but asked her if they could at least not put peppers in the taco but the woman again angrily said no they could not (since obviously we were asking for her to bring us the moon).  The unwanted taco arrived peppers and all.  

Only redeeming factor for this place was the fresh squeezed OJ.  It came in a massive cup and was on point.  Everything else was a fail. =(
author: Sylvie S.

description:
El farlito is just across the street so I usually go where the line is the shortest but I have to stay this place has the better food. 

Their super nachos are a bit small but their super quesadilla is definitely what won me over here.

There's so much flavor packed into the quesadilla, you'll find yourself using a bunch of napkins by the end of your meal.
author: Maggie C.

description:
The first time I came here my friend recommended that I try the cantaloupe juice. I was like, what's the big deal, it's just juice! Mind you, we drove from the Richmond District to get a cup of $3 juice! 

My mind was blown. It's really awesome juice. LOL! It's a definite must try. Your $3 won't go to waste. Plus, the cup is HUGE! It's almost the size of the XL cups from Taco Bell. 

I also got a order of nachos while I was waiting for juice. It was calling my name! Overall the nachos was pretty good. Nothing too fancy, but I loved that they didn't skimp on anything. PLUS, they added huge chunks of avocados! 

I'll definitely come back for more foods...maybe at their other location, because this one feels kind of sketchy (location).
author: Jess W.

description: Love this place. Great value for your $. The fajitas are great and come with a huge quantity of food that, for me, can make 3 meals for a $12 price. The salsa bar is great here too.
author: Shara M.

description:
I was walking by this place while I was in the Mission (after picking up some OTHER food), and I knew I had to stop in. I'm not a huge Mexican food fan, but the stuff looked delicious, so I decided to give it a shot.

I got a Regular Suiza with Steak to go, and damn was it delicious. No regrets there.
author: Jon N.

description:
Very good burrito.

Loud TV that no one is watching.

Whole restaurant smells like bleach.
author: D N.

description: You stupid Wednesday night at 8pm cashier bitch! The fact that I'm trying to pay for my burrito and your card machine isn't working, is not my fault and than you treat me like a second class citizen because you slammed the machine even further damaging it and can't charge me, hence snatching the burrito out of my hand as if I was a thief. Work on your interpersonal as well as intertechnological skills. Than don't go off suggesting to me that I should withdraw money at the ATM across the street that's going to charge me 50% of the burritos cost, or else you can't serve me. FUCK YOU and FUCK OFF
author: David O.

description:
Amazing tacos. 
The meat was fresh & seasoned so nice. 
The sauce is really hot/spicey but also good.
They have free nachos when you order & a salsa bar that is also free.
I've been here twice... had the chicken, shrimp, streak, chorizo & al pastor ...all delicious.. for $2.25 a taco you can't ask for more !
Oh and you can get fresh squeezed orange juice also which rules.
author: Eduardo S.

description:
Hands down my favourite mexican restaurant. I'm from Vancouver and we are known to have many great restaurants but we are definitely lacking in good mexican cuisine. 
The super tacos are massive. They are definitely not cheap about portions.
The only downfall is the salsa.
But still giving a 5 star! :)
author: Anisa C.

description:
OK, to be fair, I don't remember a ton about eating here (it may have been after a long night of bar-hopping). I just know it was deliciousness. 

My friends and I came here after a night at the Marina. I'm not entirely sure if this place is 24-hours, but it was open late, and it was amazing. I ended up getting a loaded quesadilla with chicken, and drenched it in their heavenly green salsa. My friends appeared to be quite content with the massive burritos they were given.

I would most definitely come here again - cheap delicious Mexican food at 2 in the morning is always a plus in my book!
author: Claire S.

description: I cheated on my favorite taqueria (which is across the street and won't drop names out of respect).... But yes... I can't say I was extremely impressed. It was good but didn't kick their opponents butt. I had the super quesadilla with carne asada and a melon drink. It was tasty but I didn't feel like it was enough cheese for my liking. I liked the melon drink though! The food overall wasn't bad and I feel like I need to give it another try again since I do know a lot of people who enjoy this place. Until next time....
author: Tiff C.

description: I was really looking forward to coming to this place and trying it out because of all the reviews I've seen. I was in the city on a Thursday night trying to look for a place to eat and I stumbled across Guadalajara on yelp because it was the only location on yelp that says they were opened til 4am. My group was super excited because the prices were cheap according to yelp. When we arrived we found the restaurant to be closed and an employee outside cleaning shouted that they were closed when we tried entering the restaurant. I'm not normally the type to rate low reviews but I found it completely unprofessional how the employee shouted at us. I'll change my review when I get to try it when it's opened.
author: Jun Q.

description:
In a neighborhood of quite a few Taquerias, this is one of a couple that I always recommend to first-time Mission goers ready for some super bomb Mexican food.

El Farolito, Cancun, and the usual taco shop on every corner, are all delicious. Have yet to have an unsatisfactory burrito or taco in the Mission. However, this place defines carnitas for me. Every taco is topped off with a massive heap, and if you're smart enough to get a super taco, the enormous slices of creamy and fresh avocado are the perfect pairing. The sour cream will do you in. Two of those babies and I'm done for. The carne asada is also too good to be true and you're given aplenty, but the tender, flavorful carnitas with a bit of exterior crisp will always have me coming back. Such a good deal, too!

And that unlimited salsa bar. Yes. The chips, also some of the best I've had, fill me up before I even get to the food!

You'd think that one would get used to grimy bathrooms in this food scene, but that may be the only thing here that throws me off. Having to push other patrons' leftovers to the side of the table is also no bueno, but it's not a big deal.

P.S. If you've got a big appetite and you can handle it, try the super burrito. You. Will. Be. Stuffed. And happy beyond belief.
author: Tina Y.

description: Amazing food, amazing agua frescas, SALSA GALORE and free chips. Can't ask for anything better. Inexpensive, clean, lots of space & seating in an awesome part of SF. Definitely would recommend this spot, its awesome!
author: Jessica P.

description:
This is my go-to burrito taqueria (as opposed to my go-to tamale taqueria, which is Vallarta). The veggie super burritos here are juicy, creamy, and full of flavor (and avocado!). I try not to demolish my basket of chips and drink my little cupful of thick green salsa before I get my burrito, but it's hard.

It's open relatively late, but I like going in right before the dinner rush starts and getting the table by the salsa bar so I can watch whatever telenovelas the ladies at the register are watching. If I'm with friends, I try to get a table further in so we can stuff our faces, drink our Modelos, and yell at each other in peace.
author: Bianca C.

description:
Hit up the salsa bar !!! So good. 
They accept card in the city, which is almost unheard of. Also , times of business are slammin'. This can be a delicious lunch or the best after 2am snack. 
El farralito sucks compared to this place. Best part, they are fast as hell here. No waiting in line with a bunch of drunk techies late night... 
I always go with a burrito. Naturally it's larger than my head, and stuffed full of deliciousness. I also get the super tacos which are amazing . 
OH there is also ample space to park in the neighborhood : )
author: Slam B.

description:
Cheap, clean, and with a expansive salsa bar. Totally worth it if your craving Mexican and in the neighborhood. 

Portions are very generous, food was delicious.
author: Patrick T.

description: Stopped in based on yelp reviews. I had the pastor tacos which had a different flavor than I'm used to. Not bad, just different. Their salsa was ok and I enjoyed their horchata.
author: Carole R.

description:
Open late, rarely crowded, their salsa is the best I've tried in the mission, and servings are big. Their tomatillo salsa is especially good, I think they season it a little more strongly than other taquerias. I always get an excessive number of salsa containers and finish every single one.

I usually go with a super burrito, which is pretty standard with the added plus of it's always way too big and leaves room to share or save for later. Their chips could use a little work, they are not quite as oily and crispy as other places, but perhaps that's a plus.

If you're feeling especially hungry, try a wet burrito, basically a super burrito doused in salsa and enchilada sauce. Always enjoyed, sometimes regretted for just how big and unhealthy it probably is. And another plus, not all taquerias have cabeza, but this one does.
author: Richard A.

description: Like there super nachos. I even tried there super taco but it wasn't that super. The super nachos just taste way better then there super tacos. Or maybe because there super tacos look small.
author: Anthony G.

description:
Designated capital.

Of perhaps the last $6 regular burrito in San Francisco. This one came with grilled chicken and black beans inside a wheat tortilla.

Unlike the new smaller sized trend, there was more than enough for one. But also good enough to finish in one sitting.

Inside you'll find colorful murals, a friendly staff and what just might be the new burrito capital of 24th Street.
author: Jason B.

description:
About what you would expect from a dive Taqueria on 24th street in the Mission.  Its cool because its ironic.  I mean how could something not be ironic in the mission...even if there are carbon copies littering the area.

The food was good and I didn't get sick which seems like a standard requirement, but at a mexican food place its never quite a sure thing.   

All kidding aside, this place was totally authentic.  The burrito was huge and the carnitas had a TON of flavor.  

I didn't have to wait long and the food came out hot.

I will totally be back.
author: Chad J.

description: This taqueria is worth walking away from Valencia street and getting some real good tacos.  Friendly service too.  Get some!!!
author: John P.

description: Best tacos in the mission in my opinion. Over the summer I came here ~100 times (everyday after work) and was never disappointed. Best item on the menu is the supreme grilled chicken taco. Places like El Farolito/La Taqueria are way better known, but the food takes forever to come and not much effort is put in at those places. Every time you come here the food will come fast and be consistently delicious.
author: Michael M.

description:
This review is for the chicken burrito.  I live in the Mission and have been around the block - this place has the most flavorful, moist, tender, delicious chicken burritos.  

I would go to El Farolito for steak burriitos, but this is the best place for a chicken burrito hands down.

Also, the salsa bar is a nice plus.
author: Amy G.

description: By far one of my favorite restaurants in SF. The shrimp taco is simple and delicious. I have a habit of rating good mexican with great salsa and this place tops them all. Fast and friendly.. spicy flavorful salsa. What more can you ask for
author: Adri A.

description: Mission is known for its tacos, and I have to say say, Taqueria Guadalajara is straight middle of the road. Two visits--one dine-in, and one take-out--and I left both times with a little bit of regret. It's not the best, but it's not the worst. But, what else do you want for regular tacos that cost $2.55?
author: Tik P.

description:
what i ordered... super burrito with carnitas

burrito was of good size and tasted great...... carnitas was hot, with a bit of crunch and well seasoned, guacamole was replaced of chunks of avocado which was way better, all other fillings were good too.

complimentary chips were not as good.... toooooo oily and bland


ambiance... bad (ok decor and furnitures but floor was icky dirty)
service... ok (cashier was stoic)
cost... $- (fair)
author: Gors P.

description:
Sadly i bought my burrito in a rush and missed the salsa bar. :(

This place is definitely a good value.

Got the vegetarian burrito with pinto beans. Key points:
+ $5.95 + tax (so cheap for SF standards, but perhaps a bit more expensive than nTaqueria Vallarta!)
+ Burrito is 9" + long, big enough to be two meals for me
+ Black beans, pinto beans, and rice are all vegetarian. no need to eat a rice-less or bean-less burrito, my vegetarian friends.
+ Comes with tasty crispy chips
- Could have used a bit more tomato-y / salsa-y flavors and some spiciness (but I'm sure salsa bar would have solved that)
author: Neeharika B.

description: I agree with Victor. I, too, wanted to like this place. But for now, I'll have to stick with three stars with a commitment to come back.  I was a little underwhelmed by the carne asada special burrito.  It was big, but also salty and a little on the dry side.  The salsa bar was not too impressive and even the spiciest salsa was not much so.  I'll strive to come back, but I probably wont hurry.
author: Angel S.

description:
Taqueria Guadalajara deserves an ode to a burrito poem written by yours truly.  It is officially my favorite nachos and burritos in town.  This review is only for those 2 menu items.  Their meat is very flavorful and the salsas are killer spicy.  Beware the orange habanero one is for expert spice eaters.  Love it!

I recommend ordering the nachos to go because it's so much you'll need to take some home anyway.  If you get the "super" upgrade to the nachos the chunks of avocado added to the plate are huge slices of perfection.  Do it! 

The Caldo soup is fantastic too.  I would recommend eating the soup there.  Getting it to go is too complicated.
author: Jessica G.

description: My go to burrito spot. The salsa bar for chips or the burrito itself is the best. The green and red sauce are my favorite but others are great as well.
author: T M.

description:
Perhaps the most solid option for Mexican food on or near 24th St.  Good food, good service, and a clean environment.  

Pros

-Salsa Bar.  Varied options to go with your free chips and meal.
-Soccer on TV, basically a "must" in this barrio.
-Super Suiza ($6) and Super Burrito with carnitas.  Both items are dense and hard to finish, and the carnitas are delish. 
-Comfortable tables and chairs. 
-Friendly service adds to the comfortable feel and is to credit for this place feeling cleaner than any other nearby Mexican restaurant/taqueria.
author: Heath P.

description:
Best carne asada burrito in SF
Best canitas burrito in SF
Yes, I said it.
author: James B.

description: Gaudalajara is a solid taqueria.  The food is authentic and portions are generous.  The quality of the meat is exceptional (for a taqueria) and sets it apart from the majority of surrounding taquerias.  Their salsa game is strong as well .  The only negative would be that the prices are a bit steep - $9 for a super carne asada burrito.  Overall, a great place for Mexican food if you are in the area.
author: John H.

description:
The Mission is obviously the place to go for authentic mexican food. I love walking down 24th street, looking at all of the pastries in the window, the smell of good food wafting through the air. Whenever I come to SF, I have to go eat at Taqueria Guadalajara. Their salsa bar is amazing, their portions are huge, and the staff is very friendly.
I love their super burritos, although I don't know anyone who could finish a whole one in one sitting!
If you're on 24th street and hungry, go check it out. You won't regret it.
author: Eliot J.

description: A great neighborhood burrito place. Lots of choices, and a good salsa bar. This place is always busy and has good, cheap eats.
author: John R.

description: This place is a hit or miss, depending on what you order. Their food is not consistent at all. The carne asada super nachos are delicious and great to share with one or two friends. The carnitas are a bit greasy. Also, the service is very slow. They are nice but they only have one cook and usually and three or four cashiers/servers. So be prepared to sit and have a long wait after you order. Try the crazy mayo colored salsa; I have no idea what is in it, but when it tastes this good... who cares? I would recommend Taqueria to nacho lovers like myself. The nachos are worth the wait!
author: Paul K.

description:
Walking down 24th st, craving carnitas. I peeked in Guadalajara and the Mexican leather chairs, mural and television blaring a soap opera lured me in. Very authentic, I thought.

I ordered 3 tacos with carnitas. I also got a heaping mound of "totopos" (chips), to slather in tomatillo salsa from their bar as I waited patiently. 

Oh lord....those were Guadalajara city quality tacos! I mean no plane ticket necessary, all you need to bring is a hearty appetite.
author: Hilda Z.

description: Went here tonight and tried the Al pastor super burrito. It was damn good, the fact that they put pineapple and grilled onions in it just put it over the top!! I will be back for sure!!
author: J B.

description: Great al pastor tacos, good for the price, and tanned hide seats that make sitting down a dangerous adventure.
author: Tyler D.

description:
This Taqueria Guadalajara drew inevitable comparison to its other location on Mission near Onondaga St.  We tried the shrimp burrito that is not available at the other location, and were delighted at the shrimp's freshness.  The salsas at this location were an upgrade - the habanero sauce was not only spicier, but tasted fresher as well.

Not only are Guadalajara's burritos amply satisfying, if you are lucky, the local patrons may provide entertainment as well.  We had great timing on a late Friday night to be dining at the same time as a Mexican cowboy who uncontrollably played a cultural ditty on his cell phone every couple of minutes while circling our table and making drawn-out, uncomfortable eye contact with each one of us as we were eating.  He leaned towards the ears of two of us, and laughed in an M. Night Shyamalan movie-worthy, hoarse whisper, "Hough, hough, hough, hough."  We left promptly after he decided to slide over a cup of cantaloupe juice that was undoubtedly roofied.
author: Andrew M.

description: I LOVE THIS PLACE SO MUCH! I am obsessed with shrimp tacos so I try them at different restaurants all around the world and this place has some of the best shrimp tacos I have ever had. Anytime I'm in the area I pop in here. I'm actually about to go there right now!
author: Bori G.

description: FAN-tastic - this place has everything I dream of when i'm not in California and i'm missing tacos. The carnitas and shrimp in my tacos were super juicy and well seasoned. AND i was eating at 3am. Plus fresh melon juice, I didn't have to drink yucky yucky soda. In the words of Donna Summer: I feel love!
author: J A.

description: I thought the place was dirty but smelled like ammonia or bleach.  As for the food, the al pastor meat was long and stringy which made it tough to eat...I'd prefer diced up pork instead.  I'll choose Pancho Villa over Taqueria Guadalajara any day.  The pineapple they add to the burritos and tacos is a nice addition though!
author: Nick C.

description: This is genuine mission: dark ambiance, soccer on the TV and non-English speaking help and patrons.  And the food melted in our mouths. My BF got a super burrito with chicken (delish) and I got customized tacos (2 chicken + 1 beef, both with avocado but not the cream or cheese). They totally got it right despite the language barriers. The prices are great and the meat is to die for. This is an authentic neighborhood keeper (as the history underscores).
author: Diane B.

description: I didn't like my burrito it was flavorless & the chicken tasted plain... I felt like I was eating a diet burrito.,.
author: Habibti A.

description:
I'm giving it a one star because if this place was a real Taqueria in Guadalajara Mexico it would be out of business by now. 

Let's see, very greasy tacos, cheap asada meat, pastor was fatty and chewy, corn tortillas were stale (guerrero store bought brand?).

Finally they scorched my taco meat so it had a crispy burnt flavor. The only good thing was the chips and salsa. I guess for San Francisco where authentic taquerias are non existent this place stands a chance.
author: R J.

description: Exactly what I want in a Mexican food restaurant: five+ salsa choices, reasonable prices, and friendly service. Plus, if you eat your food in the restaurant you are treated to giant wall painting of a man on a horse wooing a lady and get to sit in interesting, round leather chairs. I've eaten here a lot and I'll definitely be eating here again.
author: Nan H.

description:
Three stars for the quality of the food...but they get that extra star because they are open so late!  They are always the last taqueria open on the way back to my apartment.  This is my stop-on-the-way-home-from-bar-crawl go to spot.  Always.  And while I've tried a few different types of burritos and quesadillas (grilled chicken, pastor), I think it's best to stick with the most consistently tasty burrito - veggie super.  Lots of rice, beans, salsa, sour cream, and guacamole goodness.  Relatively cheap - $5 out the door?  Not too shabby considering I could go down to Papalote or La Taqueria and pay $10 for a burrito.  Another plus - coke in the bottle.  And I'll let you in on another secret - coke in the bottle is a magical hangover cure.  Free chips with your order, too!

I'm embarrassed to say that there have been nights where I've come in twice...but the service is always friendly and fast and there is never any judgment.  Taqueria Guadalajara, I am your number 1 fan (usually while drinking...)!
author: Jenna C.

description: Delicious! Tried their Super Nachos and Super Burritos and they were huge. The service was great, too.
author: James M.

description:
1 - Go to Taqueria Guadalara 
2 - Order the Alambres plate wrapped up in a burrito (asada, tomatoes, peppers and onions, rice, beans, and GRILLED BACON) 
3 - Baby it's plain to see, that you're the only one for me and
4 - Repeat steps 1 through 3
5 - You'll fall in love with me... for telling you about this.  

Brian McKnight said it best.  

For a great burrito, high school prom flashbacks, and spicy-ass habanero salsa, you must go to this taqueria!!!

And if you are a man, you will take a shot of that habanero salsa.
author: William S.

description:
On a hunt for some REAL grub after the SF Street Food Fest, we strolled into Guadalajara in hopes that this place would fill us up after a disappointing day of waiting in lonnnng lines and sold out grub. My cousin ordered a cow tongue taco & my brother had 2 super tacos w/ beef. The super tacos were SUPER huge! Each bite ended up in a drippy mess, but it was surely appetizing. I think he would've been satisfied with just 1 taco, but he was determined to declare his manhood by gorging on 2. Mission accomplished!...with a potbelly to prove it.

The horchata was bleh. We got the bottom of the barrel, so the ice probably melted and watered it down by then. Probably the worst horchata I've ever drank, but the complimentary tortilla chips & salsa made up for it. Red salsa = spiciness! Green salsa = winner! 

This place doesn't top Guad in Davis. ;)
author: Michelle W.

description:
This place has very Tex-Mex decorations and nicely spaced chairs and tables compared to the ever-so-crowded Farolito. Most of the entrees come with a side of chips and a salsa bar which has all your basic salsa needs. 

I love their carnitas; juicy meat attached to crispy pieces of skin, highly recommended as your choice of meat. I am a fan of their quesadilla suizas but they could grill the quesadilla a lot more on the sides but overall very good ratio of avocado, meat, and cheese. 

The burritos here are pretty simple but flavoful. I would go for the shrimp burrito despite its slight extra cost, tastes so good paired with the habanero sauce. Their shrimp is relatively fresh from what I could tell. 

The horchata I ordered was on the sweeter side but with a good minty after taste. 

Overall, a good place to sit and enjoy a meal. They have a T.V. playing futbol and Spanish soaps going on as well.
author: Alice L.

description: I went here twice on my san fran trip.  I rarely go anywhere twice in a new place as I love discovering new places.  But I had to go right before heading to the airport.  This burrito is perfection.  I had the shrimp burrito with the extra stuff- avocado, crema, etc.  So good.  Now I get what mission burrito means.  The salsa bar is so good too.  They were out of that super super spicy orange stuff when I went the second time but maybe it's a good thing as I was about to get on a plane.  My BF usually gets pork in his burrito and usually wishes he had not gotten it but at this place he was silent.  Silent and eating his burrito non-stop.  Now I get why people from the west coast whine about the shitty burritos/mexican food in NYC.  waahhhhhh
author: Jane K.

description: Encouraged by the reviews, I tried this place.  Surprisingly disappointed by my poor experience, I will not return.  First, the place.  There was only one free table that didn't have flies swarming all around it, so I chose it.  That table had someone else's unfinished food, which remained on the table as I sat there.  The lady that worked there was not busy the whole time I ate, even walking by my table a couple of times, but it apparently never occurred to her to clean the table.  Second, the food.  The chips were stale and flavorless.  The salsa did not taste fresh.  The burrito was lukewarm.  Third, the after effects.  My stomach felt sick immediately after I ate here.  I went next door to get some juice drinks to try and soothe my stomach to no avail.  The food ended up bothering my stomach all night.  Go at your own risk.
author: John J.

description: My favorite Al Pastor in the world, my favorite nachos and burritos in San Francisco. Nice people, too! Remember to tip!
author: Dom B.

description: Holy ship the tacos are amazing! And the location is perfect for drunken people-watching.
author: Mikayla H.

description: I like pretty much all food, which is why all my yelp reviews are 5 stars. My husband is picky though. I brought half of my massive carne asada super burrito home for him when he got off the late shift. When I woke up in the morning, he told me he ate it very slowly on the couch in silence, without turning on the tv or opening up his computer. He declared it the best burrito he's had since leaving San Diego...which was in 2010. Keep in mind that at the point of consumption, the burrito was already about 2 hours old. That's all.
author: Alexis H.

description:
Cold beer + fat enchiladas + comfortable seating + cheap pricing + futbol on tv = 4 stars

Definitely worth returning.
author: Roger H.

description:
Yes, the place is a bit grimy, but the food's so good. 
  The salsa bar is one of the best. The habanero sauce tasted like flaming hot cheetos, the crack of my childhood. The green salsa was creamy; they don't skimp on the avocado in that one.
  I've tried the super shrimp taco, super veggie nachos, and shrimp burrito here. The grilled veggies they put in are so tasty. 
  I like how that the shrimp taco came with grilled veggies and not a mayo sauce. It had so much food unlike the tiny Pancho Villa shrimp taco. 
  The super nachos were tasty, huge, and very difficult to finish without 2-3 people. 
  The shrimp burrito was good. The shrimp are more buttery here. They grill the burrito or tortilla, which makes the burrito taste even better.

Update on the Food Inspection Score: They now have an 84. 
Link: 
http://dph-extranet2.sfdph.org:7777/pls/eeop_htmldb/f?p=132:1:3742051178358532:pg_R_27976303043474859:NO&pg_min_row=21&pg_max_rows=10&pg_rows_fetched=10
author: Jen Y.

description:
I like this place a lot.
