I usually get a couple tacos and have yet to get a bad one.  The meat is fresh and cooked properly, the tortillas are typical for a San Francsico taqueria, the habanero salsa is amazing, and the orange juice is made while you stand there.  What's not to like?
author: Spike S.

description:
When the inevitable Burrito War begins, I will take up arms for Taqueria Guadalajara. Down with overrated and oft dissapointing El Farolito! Down with white people Papalote! Long live Guadalajara!

Without a doubt, the very best Carnitas burrito in the city. And since we all know that Carnitas is the One True Meat, it follows that Taqueria Guadalajara has the best damned burrito in the city. And unlike El Farolito the Burritos come like Swiss trains, on time and delicious.

I will fight you and your family to defend the honour of my Taqueria. The blood shall flow like Salsa Roja and the righteous crispy fattiness of their carnitas will ensure final victory.

Monkey stomp on your spinach tortilla vegan bullshit burrito.
author: EDW L.

description:
Amy's first rule of ethnic food: When you walk into a place and it's all full of white people...leave.  Well, I mean, not if it's a French restaurant.  OK...if you walk into a Mexican restaurant and it's all full of Mexican people, this is a good sign.  Spanish soaps on the boob tube?  Even better.

Well, I was starving and I got to the corner just in time to see my bus pull away.  What other solution could I have come up with but to duck into the first taqueria I saw...and order some enchiladas?

This place was great.  The food had a very homemade feel to it and the salsa from the salsa bar was actually spicy.  I hate it when the salsa isn't spicy.  ...and the other reviewer who mentioned that the chips were great?  My hero.  They were so good.  So good.

Of course it was way too much food but I pigged it down.  Did I mention that it was great?

Uno!  Dos!  Tres!  Coal-gah-tey!  (That's Colgate in gringspanglish)
author: PrincessPeac H.

description: At firs this place was good.  Now a days theyre Carne Asada Burritos always have grizzle in them.  Once i phone ordered a super burrito to pick up.  I grabbed it went home and in my burrito was only meat and rice. This is not what i ordered when i called she acted like they did nothing wrong and i was lying.  She finally offered me to go back the next day and get another Burrito.  I went and when i got there, the cashier again acted like i was lying and asked for proof that i had got anything.  She also told me they wouldn't just tell me to come in for a burrito.  After stating my case three different times and she saw the line was growing she finally gave me my burrito.  This was horrible service!!!!  I would not go again. I would rather go to El Farolito across the street, which has better quality food.
author: Dannie A.

description:
Thank you tattooed guy for recommending this place, you were right this taqueria has good burritos. 

Food:
I had the super grilled shrimp burrito and bf had the steak.  Both were very tasty, but I loved mine a lot more. I loved the blend of beans, rice, cheese and shrimps.  They all culminated into one huge orgasmic delight in my mouth.  

The complimentary chips and salsa were pretty decent also.  The chips were a bit on the saltier side but the mild spiced salsa more than compensate for the amount of salt.

Ambience:
Very colorful taqueria with funky chairs and tables.  

Overall, this place would have gotten 4 stars or even more if it weren't for the flies flying around.
author: Melissa T.

description:
Was in the Neighborhood and had a craving for an authentic 
Super Burrito , passed this place on route to La Palma, the
place I usually would go to but this time I  had my dog with me and not wanting to leave the dog hooked up too long because La Palma
would take longer because thats where the locals shop
so I came back to Guadalajara  and ordered a Steak Super Burrito
and it was the Bomb, all the flavors melded together, had some
Guacamole in there, very fresh tortilla wrapping all that wonderfulness
together. Super Burritos are $ 6.50 which is a good value for the
high quality food at Guadalajara, 24/shotwell
author: Pete C.

description:
I love to heckle this joint because there's a check cashing store attached to it, so it looks like you can get paid and buy tortillas in one shop.  I finally walked in on .Tiff's glowing recommendation and was not disappointed.  Hell, I woofed my meal down like it was the last Mexican dish I'd ever eat.

I strongly recommend hitting the Super Tacos here if you like a generous serving of avocado.  They prepare the deep fried pork in an unusually delicious way: you'll find crispy thin strips almost like Vaca Frita.  The burritos are also obscenely substantial but my pollo asado configuration wasn't exactly a signature taste.  Quite forgettable, really.

Still, overall I felt that the ingredients were better and preparation were dealt with more care than the more popular bulk-serving other taquerias nearby that often serve you wet, runny meat and beans.  It felt like the menu has some gems, and their kitchen is fun to watch.  Quality at a good price: three can eat for about $20 combined.  Quite a bargain!  I'm eager to return and experiment further.

The hand-carved branded seats and tables and wall-to-wall pueblo paitings are complete with faux wooden doors and awnings are charming, but the charm is quickly lost to the blasting soccer games on bolted-on televisions at full blast.  Unless you care for the sport you should consider taking your food to go and eat it 3 blocks up in beautiful Folsom Park or (if lazy) steal a Phil'z Coffee park bench and enjoy some hipster people watching from the corner.

Pro tip:  Try the melon juice.  They squeeze it fresh in a giant vat.  Delicious!
author: niero g.

description: My go-to place for veggie tacos in the Mission! They also give free chips and the salsa is very tasty.
author: Priscilla M.

description: This is my go-to for Mexican in the Mission. Super tacos and super burritos are the BEST. Love the ambiance and service is excellent.
author: Brooke B.

description:
This review is for the burritos only.

GOOD:
- The CARNITAS BURRITO is damn good. The pork is crisp and juicy. It probably is the least healthy meat option on the menu but damn, these folks do it right. 
- The CALDO DE REYS Y POZOLE is good for a chilly day. It is basically a big bowl of beef or pork (your choice of meat) and Latin American corn (the big non-sweet kernal kind) stewed in a rich tomato beef broth.
- They accept credit card here (rare for the Mission) and there is no minimum so I can conserve my cash for other places in the neighborhood.
- Relatively clean and spacious place for being a non-gringo spot.

JUST OKAY:
- The POLLO ASADO and the CARNE ASADA BURRITOS were okay. They were not as flavorful and good as the CARNITAS. The carne asada tended to be a bit on the dry side too.

BAD:
- None.

CONCLUSION:
- I would give this place 4.5 stars just for the carnitas burrito but the pollo asado and carne asada were just average. Aside from the meat filling, this place makes good burritos and in my opinion, the overall quality is higher than El Farolito and just a notch below Papalote.
author: Alex P.

description: We were taking advantage of this beautiful day and "Sunday Streets" which turned Valencia and 24th Streets into a car-free zone for the day. Walking down 24th Street, we stopped into Taqueria Guadalajara for a little snack. We each had a carnitas taco and I have to say it was the best taco I have ever had...anywhere, including Mexico. It was delicious and fresh and PERFECT. I'll definitely be back YUM!!!!!!!
author: bill b.

description:
When I have those late night cravings, I head out to Taqueria Guadalajara. They have huge wet burritos for a pretty reasonable price. I'm no food expert, but I won't lie I am officially addicted to La Tacqueria's carnitas so I can't say that their Carnitas is the best, but it's still pretty darn scrumptious and it hits the spot....plus I have enough left over for the next day!

Oh and they accept credit cards = )
author: Irene N.

description: Their super shrimp tacos and super quesadillas are super bomb.com (yeah, I wrote that)
author: Heather P.

description: Best carnitas in the mission hands down. It's fast, uncrowded and is more flavorful than the competition.
author: Garret T.

description:
Burritos are huge.

Tacos are awesome! so meaty and delicious! 

Super Quesadilla is a fav. 

Always get the steak or marinated pork with it. 

I've been coming here since I was little! (well always had togo) 
I bring all my friends here and they ALL LOVED it especially the guys!! And it has became something my friends and I crave all the time.  

BEST TAQUERIA i have been to!! and they open till 2am!
author: Erica L.

description: One of the fattest, most meat filled burritos I have had in the city.  Seriously, this thing was like a 5lb brick.  Thumbs up in my book!
author: Tom L.

description: There was a long hair wrapped in my super burrito. Before I saw it, the burrito tasted ok. I thought there should have been more sour cream and guacamole.
author: Rose H.

description:
This place has good salsas - both the fresh and green.  The tacos and suizas, particularly steak, are okay-edible too.  The burritos are decent, but not particularly tasty that it is memorable.  The chips are probably the pre-packaged kind and the horchata and melon fresco aren't bad.  

Service is fast, although not much is exchanged --you give your order and get the price back.  No thank yous, but then again nothing much else either no matter how many times I come here.  Hours for this place are good for those late-nights.  Good thing is the food here is stable --taste is consistently the same as is menu, service, portions, and atmosphere.

Downsides would probably be the safety as is mentioned in other reviews, but what can you really expect in Excelsior late at night?  Anyhow, this is a pretty OK place for that late night Mexican food run.
author: Jennifer Y.

description: I really liked this place!  The atmosphere reminded me of Mexico, and the food here was even better than the Mexican I had food in Puerto Vallarta on my last trip.  Fast service and decent prices, too.
author: Ryan S.

description:
I came here the other week with some friends to eat burritos and watch some soccer. I'm a very ambitious eater and I often think I can pound out numerous burritos in one setting. Five minutes later I'm usually lying down on the ground sweating sour cream and screaming for someone to take the elephant out of my stomach. There are many taquerias in the Mission that I have left via gurney (and one time i was airlifted to the nearest hospital).    

Anyway, the regular burrito here is super huge and also super good. They cram it with everything you could want. It is kinda expensive ($8.50) but it does fill you up and most normal people will probably take some of it home for later. I am not normal, however, and I absolutely destroyed the burrito de carnitas. I seriously wolfed it down like I have not wolfed down anything in awhile. 

As for the location, it is one of the nicer places to eat in the area. Maybe not as nice as the Taqueria Guadalajara in Fruitvale (I don't think the two are related) but it's still a cool place to come on a Sunday afternoon and watch some futbol - that is, if your "goal" is to enjoy a great burrito.

P.S. Pun intended.
author: Lupe P.

description:
RELIABLE MEXICAN FOOD IN THE MISSION

This is my old stand by when I am in the Mission and I want something good and predictable.

Chicken Nachos
Chips topped with grilled chicken, beans, salsa, sour cream and guacamole.  This is enough for two people to share but I wish they used different chips.

Shrimp Taco
I wasn't expecting the shrimp taco to be that exciting but it was tasty.  It had five grilled shrimp on two corn tortillas with salsa.

Their salsa bar is better than most places but their chips are terrible.  They have a habenero salsa that is extremely hot.  Don't say I didn't warn you.
author: Rob L.

description:
As far as late night Mexican food goes the only time it gets better is when you're wasted or when its the middle of the week and you went to a concert so you didn't have to get dinner and now you're walking home from BART and you're effing starving.

As you can tell, the latter is a very specific need and in this case Taqueria Guadalajara delivered the goods.  I got a couple of chicken tacos with avocado, cheese, hot sauce and sour cream.  In the words of a Nor-Cal native, "Hella."  

Did the tacos blow my mind?  Nah.  They were good and I'm sure they have some stuff that is really good; especially when you go there and everything is right off the grill or pan instead of hanging out for a bit.

That leads me to a final thought about late night Mexican food.  With a great science fiction movie or fantasy novel the viewer or reader must suspend belief.  (Trust me this is going somewhere).  With late night middle of the week after concert essentially street food I sort of take it for granted that 9 out of 10 places will not live up to every law, code, ordinance, and rule that the state of California puts in place.  Then I quickly remember my time in Thailand where a health inspector from California would lose his mind.  People, including tourists, do just fine for the most part in many places with out Health Inspectors.  

So just like a great science fiction novel, suspend your belief, sack up and take a bite of that burrito!.
author: Andrew K.

description: Hands down, this is my favorite burrito in San Francisco. Order the "Alambres Burrito". It's not on the menu. Bacon, grilled onions and bell peppers, guac, beans, rice. It's all groovy. You have your choice of meat but I always order it with Chorizo. It is the tastiest thing you can possibly get in the Mission at 2am. Tested and approved sober too.
author: Jason T.

description: Me and the BF headed there after reading all the great reviews.  This place does not disappoint at all....it is a great place.  Ordered the carnitas nachos...so very yummy!  Also, had a chicken soft taco.  Great value and portions are very generous.  The place as quite busy for a Saturday afternoon, but plenty of seating.  I would highly recommend this one!
author: Cheryl J.

description: I try to avoid writing negative reviews, but I have to do this.  I've been to the Taqueria Guadalajara on Mission street many times and it has never disappointed me, but this location is an entirely different story.  The other night I was craving Mexican food and decided to try this place out.  I ordered the Alambres dish with shrimp, which is what I always get at their Mission street location.  It took a while for the food to arrrive, but when it did I immediately dug into the refried beans.  COLD!  I don't mean lukewarm, but cold!  And the flavor left so much to be desired.  I love rice and beans, but these were just awful. I was about to move on to the Alambres when I noticed a hair in my food.  I tried to pull the hair out, but it was completely wrapped around the steak and shrimp!  It took me three attempts to get the hair out, and when I finally did, about a quarter of my food came off the plate with it!  It was disgusting!  The hair was so long that one would think Rapunzel herself had cooked the meal!  I was starving, so I tried to ignore it and eat the food on the other half of the plate.  Wish I hadn't. The food was so bland.  After one bite my appetite was gone, but unfortunately the memory of the hair will forever remain.
author: Victoria G.

description:
After grabbing some coffee from Philz the other day, I knew I had to get some lunch for the next day.  I stopped by Taqueria Guadalajara for a pastor quesidilla in yet my continuing quest for the perfect pastor, spicy and meaty with just enough grease to make it taste like pork.

Sorry to report, my quest will continue.  This pastor was almost sweet.  As in sugar sweet, not spicy, or zesty.  

The salsa was pretty good, but if you want pastor, go elsewhere.  Nice atmosphere, but have I been asleep for so long, that a suiza now costs almost $7??
author: Michael M.

description:
Great food, friendly staff, and reasonable hours.  Their chicken burrito is quite delicious, carnitas tacos are ridiculously delicious, green salsa is to die for, and their shrimp nachos are a late-night must!  Highly recommended, and our favorite taqueria so far in the "lower 24th Street corridor."

P.S.  We are so happy that El Farolito keeps winning all of the burrito contests.  Yeah, everyone, go there and wait in line forever for over-rated Mexican food - stay away from my Guadalajara!
author: Julie L.

description:
Taqueria Guadalajara is a destination burriteria for me. I go out of my way to hit this place up. 

Without fail I order a super chicken burrito, light on the rice but heavy on the beans, and so I cannot speak to anything else on the menu. Without fail, however, I have the burrito experience I am looking for at TG. I love it. It's always just big enough, and just tasty enough, and it's never sloppy. These guys are real artisans. Consistency is the true hallmark of professionalism. 

The salsa bar is great, too. They have some salsas you don't see elsewhere, like this carrot/mango/vinegar number that tastes delicious yet sticks with you, spice-wise. Radishes. Orange habenero salsa (complete with an English-language spiciness warning).

I don't know what else to say here.
author: Maple Q.

description:
This place is awesome! If you want to find a stick in your burrito. Do you want to find a stick in your burrito? Hmmm....Interesting!

Also, my bag got snatched from here, and I wasn't being oblivious. It just vanished as if by magic.
author: Ima D.

description:
i really wanted to like this place.

(pros)
 the cashier was nice. the carne asada burrito (5.50) came out within 7 minutes. it was hugh.. the free chips were fresh and delish. the salsa bar had pretty of sauces.
-burrito is a good value. meat tender.

but
(cons)
-the burrito had too much pinto beans and not enough salsa.
-the improper mix made a bland burrito. (which adding salsa from the salsa bar will cure).

a return trip is warranted.
author: Victor G.

description:
So tonight I'm like, "I wanna get me some good enchiladas, but let's try someplace new, I've already been to that place with the awesome fake stone walls a couple times."

So I do a Yelp search, and I find this place that's supposed to make awesome shrimp enchiladas, and I've never had those before.

So we go, and when we're about half a block away I'm like, "Hey, wouldn't it be funny if this turned out to be that same fake Spanish fortress place?"

And funny enough, it was. And I got the shrimp enchiladas, and they were rad, and the boyfriend got carnitas super nachos, and that was awesome too. And the decor was still the coolest in the Mission, too.

They have a liquor license now, for the record. They also now serve four different varieties of flour tortillas. And some awesome pico de gallo.

I think next time I gotta get the fajitas, 'cause they came to the table behind us, and they looked amazing.
author: Lynae Z.

description: Sometimes I dream about this place. I always get the Super Nachos with grilled chicken. I LOVE that they put avocado on practically everything. Plus they're open pretty late & accept card.
author: Allison C.

description: Aaah god this place is soo good! I just had a taco and I found this place randomly!
author: Ashley L.

description:
Al pastor is my favorite taqueria meat, but for some reason good al pastor is hard to come by in SF. I'd like it a bit spicier, but otherwise Guadalajara does a decent job of it with the traditional chunks of pineapple and onion marinated with the meat, and the taco servings are hefty! 

I also love a good salsa bar, which they have going on here, but as others have noted their chips suck.

Also a good place to catch up on your Mexican telenovelas (at full volume) while eating.
author: Aimee G.

description:
We halted our quest for the best 24th St. burrito after Guadalajara. 

While it's not the clean, fresh burrito of Papalote (and it's not trying to be), it's a silver missile of delicious served hot enough to burn your greedy little mitts. The pollo asado is good (though can be rather 'chickeny' at times), and Adam swears by their variation of pastor (sweeter, less barbequed but still awe-inspiring). The salsa bar deserves accolades for both the flavors as well as the sign above it that bears a pepper with muscular arms wearing bandoliers. 

They also seem to abide by the unofficial rule to have a scale among the 25 cent tschotske dispensers in the back. Taqueria San Jose has one too, and it always baffles me - why have a scale, that you pay to use, in a place destined to add pounds to your frame?
author: Carla C.

description:
Awesome food. My favorite place for breakfast burritos (which are HUGE), my boyfriends favorite for menudo (the best mexican hangover food). I also love their guacamole salsa stuff. Super tasty and just the right amount of spice for my Irish pallet. 

I give this place a lower rating because the last time we came in the lady working the register here was on her cellphone the WHOLE time. It may have been for business, but I work at a shop and I know to put down the phone when helping a customer. 

Won't stop me from coming here again or recommending this place to my friends whenever they want a gargantuan burrito.
author: Cake S.

description:
Two chicken super tacos & horchata please!  $8 max.

If your not as hungry, one super taco does the trick too.
author: Justin P.

description:
I decided to stop in and check out the new taco joint. It's just been remodeled, so if you have a thing about clean taquerias this might be your new favorite place. The kitchen is also very open so you can see what the cook is up to, which may or may not be a good thing in the long run.

The menu and prices were exactly average for the Mission. The quality of the food was better than average though.. good corn tortillas (lightly grilled, which was nice), decent salsa and chips, very good pollo asada.

Overall the place is more like a 3.5, but the service was good and they have a couple more spicy pickled things on their salsa bar than your usual place, so let's just round it up.
author: erik h.

description: The tortilla here is awesome.  The carne asada was salty as hell.  I like salt but my fat shriveled after I ate all the meat.  I left drunk and disappointed.  :(
author: Fatty A.

description: Not a place that I would initially visit myself.  My older cousin's bf brought all of us here one hungover morning and I've been there a few more times after that with them.  It's a really great place - you get a very home-welcoming feeling.  Quite the hole-in-the-wall with exceptional food!  Everything is fantastic with great flavors.
author: Amy L.

description:
After leaving the Street Food Fest hungry and tired, we stumbled into Guadalajara in search of sustenance. After much debate, I ordered 2 pastor super tacos and a horchata, and cousin went with a lengua taco.

Seating was limited on a late Sat afternoon, but we're guessing that had a lot to do with food fest deserters. The chips were on the salty side but we were hungry and scarfed them down. The pico de gallo was a bit lacking in freshness, but the avocado salsa more than made up for it. I'm glad I only ordered 2 tacos - they were huge. The tortillas were loaded beyond capacity, and I'm glad I was able to finish them off before they completely disintegrated from the grease and juice and all. Pastor had plenty of deliciously crunchy bits with a couple pieces of fat (the bad for you but good for flavor type) mixed in for good measure. Tried the lengua and was expecting a bit more flavor, wasn't really enough to make me go ooh yum. Could've done without the cheese but I enjoyed the avocado. Oh, and there is such a thing as too much sour cream, though I still ate it all up.

I left full, happy, and bordering on food coma. I was healed, yippee!
author: Mike W.

description:
Please note that this five-star rating is based solely on the one dish I always order there. I've never bothered ordering another damn thing on the menu because the SHRIMP SUPER TACO ROCKS MY FUCKING FACE OFF. 

If you go this fine establishment and DON'T order the shrimp super taco, don't come crying to me later. 

Seriously: shrimp super taco.
author: kdub ..

description:
Mmmm...Alambres.  This place knocks me up with food babies.

Pretty much everything I like about this place has already been said, and I agree.

And they have 2 large screen TVs that are always showing soccer in the evenings (yes they have SkySportsTV).  Grab a few beers and hang out.

* * *

Ha ha! Right-on Sig N.!  Segnior Pizza Hombre can rot in hell.

* * *

I just realized a short while ago that when I eat dead cow here, I'm also sitting on and setting food on a table made of dead cow.  Go check-out their furnishings and decor...of all the taquerias in SF, this place actually planned and spent money on their ambiance.
author: Bruce L.

description:
I eat too many burritos. And when I eat burritos I eat too much at one time. Guadalajara's burrito made me over indulge. 

It was cold and gray outside, so I used their hot to the core super burrito for $6.50 to warm me from the inside out. The super picante habenero salsa helped with the warming too, leaving my lips burning for about 15 minutes afterward.

The pastor was a little too fatty for me, way fatty actually. Some people like this. I did appreciate the grease sauteed sweet onions that snuck in with the stewed pork. My man's carnitas were better, with a nice smoky char and crispy bits. 

I love sour cream and they gave me so much I feel guilty the next day. As it should be. And I loved the salty chips, so much better than the unflavored greasy cardboard at most other places.

No real veggie options besides no meat. But you could add the pickled veggies from the large salsa bar to jazz it up.

Oh, and the decor is over the top. The murals, the chairs, the faux building facades. It's a kitschy gem.
author: Lauren G.

description:
Burritoeater.com noted that the carnitas here are "exceptional," and I agree completely.  But it referred to the ingredient mix as "flummoxing."  It appears that the highly-skilled burrito technicians at TG have learned something in the interim.  This is a 4.5-star taqueria.  [See UPDATE 7/14/07 - five stars, plus].

My super burrito with black beans was huge, well-grilled, and had a very well balanced mix of ingredients, including plentiful slices of avocado.  There was no shortage of melted cheese, but the pico made a cameo appearance only in selected bites.   Minus half a star.

Rice usually doesn't win any flavor contests with me, but it held its own here.  All of the ingredients tasted very fresh.

This was my 2nd visit.  I ordered al pastor on my first, which was kind of bland and disappointing, so I subtracted half a star.  But I'll definitely return to try other meats.  One of these weekends I'll try their birria.

The only real downside to visit no. 2 was that I hate seeing good food go to waste.  My burrito was merely massive, and I barely finished it.  My friend (who ordered the same burrito as I did) got a gi-normous stomach distender that went a little unfinished.  

This place is very clean, including the kitchen and bathroom.  That's worth at least a bonus half-star.

UPDATE 7/14/07: my "mixto" burrito with carnitas and al pastor broke the meter, blasting past 5 stars.  Wow.  The huge foil cylinder was so hot, I had to wait a few minutes before I could even pick it up.  I unwrapped a perfectly-grilled tortilla with a wall of cheese and a textbook ingredient mix.  

Even the salsa was great -- the not-to-be-toyed with mango-habanero made a cameo appearance, and the pico was spicy, flavorful, and well-balanced.  Grilled onions and huge chunks of avocado rounded out the veggie contingent.  

Stellar in every way.  Stel-lar.
author: Steve K.

description:
Stopped in here after a late night at the climbing gym for a quick bite to eat and was pleasantly surprised. 

I live less than a block from this place and love mexican food, so I don't know why it took me so long to go here. I got a super burrito with all the fixin's. It was delicious and I couldn't eat it all in one sitting. (Alright, lets be honest, I COULD have eaten it all, but I didn't want to stuff myself.) The meat (chorizo) was delicious and all of the other toppings seemed fresh.

The ladies at the counter were really nice and I got to watch some bubble gum blowing contest on the TV as I waited for my burrito, so that was fun.

I would definitely go back here again (and probably will every week) for a good, moderately priced burrito.
author: Josh C.

description: Not a bad spot to check out.  I'm a salsa kind of guy and the spicier the better.  The habanero salsa is on hit, brings on a bead of sweat to my forehead.  The burritos aren't bad and the portion of protein is very generous along with three other choices of tortillas besides the typical flower tortilla.
author: Matt M.

description:
Started off with some great potential when I walked in.  Service was nice, they had a good salsa bar, a pretty decent drink selection, etc..  I ordered the chicken enchilada plate because the picture sold me.  When it arrived the chicken seemed old and dry and the rice seemed to have been made around that same time.  And old rice is kind of a bummer.  Overall pretty lackluster.
Anyway, that was my first time eating there.  I typically don't like to base my decisions on a single dining experience so I will have to go back.
author: Ian P.

description: Its all here; authenticity, originality, tasteful food, and awesome service. The greatest draw is the tasty meat they have. I've been going to El Farolito down on Alabama my whole life and their quality has gone down hill since I was a kid. Plus Guadalajara isn't over run with annoying hipster invaders like Farolito is. Absolutely fucking delicious.
author: Rio A.

description:
After obsessively trying every highly-rated (4 stars +) taqueria in the Mission (no, really), Guadalajara comes in as my favorite for a number of reasons. It is much more out of the way than Cancun, for example, and has a pleasanter atmosphere, but it's just as cheap. And they're super clean, friendly, and consistent. Their carnitas are also the best I've ever tasted, in SF or anywhere else for that matter. And the tacos have fresh slices of avocado.

A few other taquerias may have individual items that are better than Guadalajara (e.g. camarones burrito at Papalote), but this place serves up the standards better than anyone else. And it's never crowded like Farolito or Papalote.

It's my everyday taco fix.
author: Joe H.

description: I love it. Best chicken super burrito I've had in the city. The chicken is crispy and the size is generous. yummmm
author: Corvus C.

description: I  didn't like their burrito's very much. They were not spiced well.  The carne asada was nothing special, and the meat was chopped to small.  Why is everyone rating this taqueria so well.
author: elissa s.

description:
Grilled chicken burrito is a real mind-bending experience. It opened my eyes to a whole new world. I ate it last night, and almost quit my job this morning to follow my childhood dream of being a roadie for the Solid-Gold dance squad. 

Same secret spices as Carne Asada, but no pool of grease for when you're eating healthy, and better texture that's a sensuous mix of firm and tender. It's almost too good. It's like I usually get a few really good bites out of a burrito's sweet spots, and the rest are still good, but not the same. Every single bite of this burrito was the sweet spot from every other burrito I've eaten. After a few bites, I started feeling guilty and asking myself, "What did I do to deserve such a great burrito?" 

This burrito has been added to my reasons for living. I want to be buried with a regular grilled chicken and a regular carne asada. One in each hand, tin foil started for me in case I can't move my elbows.
author: Ari B.

description:
I went here for the first time yesterday, walking up 24th St. toward Mission and remembering I was hungry. Guadalajara was the first taqueria in my path, so I went in. I loved the weird 70s-basement-meets-50s-western-saloon-movie decor. And they offered two unusual salsas: one habanero (okay) and one creamy one, made from lettuce, habaneros, tomatillos and oil (interesting, but a little too thick and rich to eat with chips). The other salsas are your standard pico and verde, and both were fine.

I had a vegetarian burrito, and was underwhelmed. It was okay. It wasn't un-tasty. But it was very bland, and reminded me of eating burritos in places other than California. I don't know what other places (Cancun, El Toro, Farolito) do to make their veggie burritos so mouth-wateringly delicious, but this place lacks that magic ingredient.

It sounds from the other reviews that the meat dishes are tasty, so I'm not ruling this place out for the future, but it's not a place I'd think of going out of my way for with so many other burritos to choose from within a block or two.
author: Tarin T.

description: While everyone is all fevered up for El Farolitos, I'm busy going Ga Ga for Guadalajara. Which is good, since it keeps the lines short. My super burrito c-c-combo breaker (grilled chicken with black beans and no sour cream) is one tasty creation over at Guadalajara. If they only had a side of guacamole for take-out, I'd be a five-star-er, but for now it's my perfect neighborhood burrito go-to.
author: Tiff C.

description: Some people buy cars for their looks, I buy burritos for the salsa. The SPICIER the salsa, the happier I get. These guys make a good burrito, but their salsa bar has a good variety and a habanero salsa that will put hair on your chest! Its a lil bit tangy for my taste, but for the endorphins it releases makes it completely worth it.
author: Vivek N.

description:
As I walked in I couldn't help but say, "Mr.Pizza Man used to be here."

More to come....

Months later 03/18/2007:  I'm really missing Mr. Pizza Man and now there's this taqueria *sigh.*  Like we need anymore around, right? So, here's what I've got to say...

The super nachos con carne really satisfied my hunger.  It's huge, duh it's super. 

I made the mistake of getting a vegetarian burrito with sour cream, the mistake being ordering with sour cream.  

Self-serve salsa area. 

There's a jukebox.

and it's clean.
author: Glu C.

description: I am a burrito connoisseur, and 24th is the heart of Mission burritos. I tried this place today, and am satisfied to say that it deserves a place among the best on the Mission. The tortilla was particularly impressive; crispy and heavily-flavored, and the rest of the ingredients were great too. The horchata wasn't anything special, but the chips were good!
author: Ned D.

description:
I live in the area and have tried many of the burrito joints in the neighborhood.  After all my tasty research, this has become my regular place when I've got a hankerin for a big ol burrito.  I've tried all the meats they offer and liked them all but the prawn.  It was kinda weird.  But let's not dwell on that one weird burrito when I've had at well over a dozen others from this place and have loved them all.  Plus they have a bitchin salsa bar (try the habanero) and complimentary chips.  AND they take credit card.  AND it's pretty cheap.  AND they're open pretty late.
If you're jonesin for some good, quick mexican, check this place out.
author: Charlie E.

description: Just got back from Mexico City. This is pretty damn close...
author: Mike V.

description:
It's a shame...with such a wonderful salsa bar (one of the best I've seen lately) the chips are those boring, cardboardy, costco type.  We split the regular nachos..they were really tasty believe it or not despite the generic chips.  They had plenty of beans, cheese, homemade pico de gallo, fresh avocado, and sour cream.

The girl at the counter was kind enough to turn down the earsplitting TV that was stuck on a commercial loop.  It's all about the food, next time a burrito to soak up all the yummy salsas.  Try the habanero one, it'll put a hitch in your giddy-up.
author: Brye L.

description:
Hell yes!

The secret door in the gigantic mural warrants a few stars on its own.  The food was also mighty tasty, although my opinion could have been biased, having arrived con mucho hambre from the Elbo Room late on a Friday night.  I liked randomness of the clientele represented by the presence of the candy ravers, but mostly I loved my delicious vegetarian mound of salsa-guac-rice-beans-etc-etc goodness.  Best late-night mexican I've had.  Thus far.  I foresee this one being a keeper.
author: Patricia D.

description: Yum. What can you really say about a taqueria in the Mission? The tacos are piled high, the carnitas are good, the salsa is hot and the place is really clean. My friend got some enchiladas and those were awesome too. Will be back.
author: Beth D.

description:
YUM. The melon juice has become a habit. So good. 
The service is great, everyone there is really nice and I like that you can see the chefs at work through the windows on the street. They often waive or smile, and they make such yummy food. Everything here is delicious- it's not the kind of place you have to question and wonder if ordering fish is bad idea. The burritos are fantastic, flavorful and juicy.
The salsa bar is perfect- pickled carrots, onions, jalapenos etc, salsas that range from hazardous to mild. My boyfriend admitted that the yellow salsa was hot enough for him- which never happens. he's the kind of person that drinks the left over salsa from his plate and often complains that no one will serve him food that's spicy enough. 
 I live close by and this place has become my go to "I'm hungry and didn't go grocery shopping this week" place. I love the seating and the tables too- real leather chairs that are comfortable and rustic. So- if you're in the neighborhood and want something tasty and don't want to eat a large portion of your wallet- go here.
author: Stephanie C.

description: Went there 8-20-11 11:40pm'ish after the karaoke ended at the napper tandy.  This is my 3rd consecutive saturday at this eatery, ordered the super quesadilla con pollo asado with horchata and complimentary chips.  The food is fairly good, I noticed it includes the salsa and avacado within the quesadilla (different from other mex eateries).  I haven't been to a mexican taqueria for a good 7 or 8 years already.  On the first saturday, since I was hungry and trying to sober up further, this taqueria caught my attention before going to my vehicle. This is definitely better than chevy's.
author: Jer W.

description:
Solid 4 star review.

I have had the super chicken burrito and the Suiza steak quesadilla.  Both were excellent. I really like the decore of this place. It goes a step behind what is expected at your average Taqueria. The chairs and tables are bound with leather. 

The second time I ate at the establishment and was really impressed when after they delivered the food to our table, they came back 10 minutes later to check in with how were enjoying our food. 

Thank you Gudalajara for going a step beyond what was expected.
author: Adam L.

description:
I have the obvious favorite burrito place being a vegetarian - but sometimes I crave the super normal no  soyrizo nonsense.
Luckily I live a block away from guadalajara! Being a neighbor, we got the the notification of a beer license, and I was sad to see yet another burrito place going in - what about a deli? But one night we wandered in, and it is a favorite. 
The BF loves the huge and delicious nachos, I go veg or shrimp burrito. Rice is tasty, not too much, cheese perfectly melted, shrimps are good and huge. The salsa bar is wonderful, the chips need help.
Once they get some better chips, they get five stars. Plus the lady that works the counter is really nice.
author: amy b.

description:
This is the cleanest taqueria in the Mission that I've been to.  The food is above average but the salsa's are below average.

The ambiance and art are nice and the bathroom is actually clean.

Price is right, but compared to some of the other places in the area, I would probably not come back.
author: Ankur P.

description:
3 Stars for the wicker chairs!
1 Star for the good food!

I wish I had a funny story to write about this place.  I just don't think my regular story will be that funny, and it's not really something you can force....or can you...?

So we go in and get this, there's a line of about 3 people, omg!  So we wait and line and you wouldn't even believe it but we made small talk, yeah i know...small talk, while we waited and choose what we wanted!  Then, lol we ordered our food!!!111one.  Sat in the wicker (seriously? wicker?) chairs for about 4 minutes, then you'll never believe this hilarity, but they gave us our food!!  Then we took it down the street and ate it like the clowns we were.


Nope, not a funny experience.
author: Levi B.

description:
The Atmosphere:
Pretty damn cozy even on a grey San Francisco afternoon.
Warm, nice tables, and interestingly engraved faux leather chairs.

The Food:
The Super Prawn Taco rocked my day + my night.
I used to regularly get the Super Prawn from Pancho Villa on 16th but this one was in a class by itself.
Maybe it was the bell pepper. Maybe it was the onion.
Maybe it was that all of it was grilled to perfection.
It's true what Spatial K. says - you can get shrimp anything here + it will be good.
author: Eboni H.

description:
First time here for lunch today. Had the ranchera burrito al pastor. I found the meat well-marinated and spicy, not sweet as mentioned by Michael M. Great salsa bar -- got a massive capsaicin high off the very flavorful habanero salsa. Would be 5 stars but for the relatively weak chips and a bit of gristle in the meat. Lack of iced tea seems odd, too. Will definitely be coming back.

Update: gristle seems to be the norm, so downgraded to 3.
author: Fred C.

description: Sorry guadala but your burrito just isn't cutting it. Sure the tortilla was soft and luxurious and your green salsa had my taste buds cheering and screaming but the quality of the burrito innards were only so-so. I like my veggie burritos loaded with goodies and well mixed. Yours was incredibly rice laden and had some funky lettuce. The black beans were tucked into a small 'corner' of the burrito and never had their chance to shine. I'm pretty sure the cheese and sour creme were MIA and damnit I love my dairy. There are so many great taquerias in the mission that I just can't get behind this one.
author: Cori W.

description: I had an unmemorable burrito here. So unmemorable, I can't recall what kind, but I'm sure it was decent.
author: Maximillian M.

description:
yummy tacos,  HUGE quesadillas, and much more.  they have a fresh salsa bar with many degrees of spiciness to sweltering burn your face off.  pick up some grub and hit up one of the many local bars, or stop by for a late night snack after a night of imbibing.  

the chairs looked pretty authentic with their animal hyde covering, and weaved wood.  i was a bit put off sitting on them, but i was also eating a chicken quesadilla that evening, so there wasn't much to say after that.
author: Sheri N.

description: The carnitas super taco is fabulous. I dont like the nachos as much.
author: Stephanie W.

description:
This is one of my top 5 burrito joints.  They make a mean burrito here.  They have the whole process down.  good ingredients, good mixture, good wrap strength, wrap variety, good salsa.  what more can you want.  

The wicker seats and tables are a nice decor sort of thing for the little Mexican joint.  Sturdy, cheap, and useful.

The salsa bar is great here (as mentioned above). they have a solid variety in both heat levels and types of ingredients.  be careful of the orangie  habanero salsa.  it may look more mild, but will burn you like no other.  heh.

I used to live right near there and haven't been back in a few months.  But my craving for their delicious burrito has me planning on going back very soon.  

Guadalajara I love thee
author: Andrew r.

description: This has been a favorite tacqueria for me for the last year, and I eat there twice a month on avaerage.  When its good its amazing.  But the quality of the food is inconsistent, sometimes so-so and the orders aren't always correct, but until last Friday, always okay.  However, Friday they hit a new low serving me food that was inedible!  I ordered shrimp tacos and vegetarian nachos.  The tacos were so burnt I couldn't gag them down, and the nachos had neither cheese nor salsa.  I write this review in hopes they will read it and improve.
author: Ziadee C.

description:
Very good quesadillas here, I would recommend the shrimp.  Also good salsa at the salsa bar and the free chips are excellent.

Nice friendly atmosphere and 2 TVs showing soccer add to the experience.

It's also nice not the stick to everything you touch.
author: Keith B.

description:
First off, I am from San Diego.  I know some good taco shop.

That said, this place was so surprisingly good!!  Granted all I had was a shrimp quesadilla but it was the bomb dot com!!

Minus one star because their chips were bad.  They were like imitation Tostitos if you get my drift.  Those big 10lb Costco bags of yellow corn chips.  Yuck.

But the girl behind the counter was a DOLL.  Didn't charge us corkage, know what i'm sayin??

It's the best, well, second to Papalote, taco shop I've had in the city.  Loves it!
author: Kicker ..

description:
favorite taqueria in the mission I would say. Or on the planet. Same thing. Veggie tacos are delicious and soo cheap! its 1.95 for a huge veggie taco with avocado and cheese and everything! plus the salsa bar is deeelicious. Burritos are good here too. 

Its always a bummer when you get some delicious mexican food late at night when you are drunk and you rave about how good it is, only to return and find that it is very mediocre at best.  Such is not the case for this place, its just as good sober as it is drunk!
and its open pretty late. in fact, I have no idea when they close.
author: Sarah B.

description: Food poisoning, yay!
author: Jim S.

description: My friend and I both agreed that this should get 3.5 stars. It was very good (not great), filling, and reasonably priced.
author: Kris B.

description: I came here starving but I have to say that the super burrito was tasty and filling, not to mention an awesome deal. The burritos are filled with real ingredients (not lettuce or rice) and the meat is marinated with a lot of flavor. The atmosphere is typical of a quick Mexican place complete with futbol on the tele.
author: Terry H.

description: BEST vegetarian burrito in the mission!... Not greasy SOOOO good. This is my #1 Taqueria. And a really good kept secret ;)
author: Katie P.

description: Biggest quesadilla ever,EVER.Like the food a lot but the chicken for my quesa was slightly over cooked last night.All in all though this place is delicious whenever I've had food here
author: Lauren V.

description:
Just OK.  I can name half a dozen spots with better, bigger, and more flavorful Mexi-fare and burritos in the area.  It was edible, but a little anemic in flavor department.  Maybe I caught them on a day where the chef got dumped by his amor.  Maybe the kitchen ran out of chile verde.  If those things happened then I'll happily give them another try.  But then again, if my aunt had balls she would be my uncle.

I liked the seating, and the Mexican Novelas on TV (those are soap operas for all you gringos) because there are always foxy ladies who can't act in them.  What are the Novelas about?  No se! I don't find these silly details important.
author: jacob s.

description: Had a carne asada burrito here a few nights ago (well, I took it home, but you get the idea).  The burrito was good and all, but the real star of the show was the chips!  WOW!  they were some of the best tortilla chips I've ever had.  omg.  crispy without being crunchy and hurty on my mouth.  yum.
author: Jennifer L.

description: The food here is awesome.  Authentic real El Pastor with Pineapple.  You can get a burito here with Two Kinds of meat for only .40 cents more.
author: Shawn L.

description: This was my late night spot when I lived in the Mission.  Carne Asada was great, but the nachos were better - even when reheated the morning after :/ (gross, I know, but really delicious).  They put soooo much avocado on those things!!  Friendly service and a guaranteed hangover cure.  That's all I ask of a taqueria.
author: Susan M.

description: This used to be the Mr. Pizza Man across the street from El Tonayese. The crappy pizza joint has been nicely remodeled into a taqueria. By nice I mean it's a step up from El Farolito, El Tona, etc. Somewhere along the lines of a La Taqueria, Pancho Villa  - meaning you can sit at a table in a fairly clean enviroment (with hand painted murals and chairs with the name branded into the leather backs) and have some good Mex. I don't know if it's associated with the other Guadalajara but I'll check next time I'm there and report back. So what's the point? Along the 24th Street Corridor this is a nice addition to go along with the renovated Roosevelt Tamale Parlor - a nicer taqueria (decor wise) with solid food. Beer/wine license is in the work and if they (could) served margaritas, they'd get another star.
author: Sig N.

description: Huge and tasty Burrito, but $9.17 is steep for a super pollo asado and a Mexican-Coke-In-A-Bottle.
author: Jason R.

description: Got two super tacos, steak and grilled chicken.  Cheese, avocado, onions.  I held the sour cream and cilantro.  Their salsa bar had two choices I really enjoyed, a red and a green.  They were grinding up fresh lime while I was there for the salsas so you know it's good stuff.  When the tacos arrived at my table, I almost gasped and the generous slices of high-quality avocado in each small taco.  Red hot salsa was nice in the tacos.  With the included chips, this 2 taco lunch with water was more than enough to fill me up and was extremely satisfying for $6.50 after tax.  I liked it a bit more than my other favorite across the street, Tonayense , which is also very nice, but this spot it a bit better.  Nicer ambiance and a bit cleaner.  Cool, comfortable chairs.  I contend that the key to finding a good restaurant is to get off the main streets because these places have to be outstanding to survive off the tourist / clubbing tracts.
author: Marc S.

description: I loved coming here for some good tacos de camaron, but after going twice and getting raw shrimp. Last time, I told the lady the shrimp was raw, she looked at me like I was crazy and asked what I wanted her to do with it. I said if I could have another, and make sure the shrimp was cooked. It wasn't 5 min when she came back with a new taco, and the shrimp, again, uncooked. Not returning here
author: Jess S.

description:
The good: Clean. The salsas are quite good. Open nightly past midnight. Accepts ATM & credit cards. Clean bathrooms. Nice ambiance. Sweet murals. Good service.
The Bad: I was very  hungry and I couldn't 't eat more than a couple of bites of that horrendous Burrito. Can be problematic outside, in front of the place, I once saw a beer bottle thrown at lady near me by an unknown drunk late one evening,. She was scared and  traumatized. Poor woman.  The Neighborhood.

Experience: Tonight at midnight, I was quite hungry, and went to  Taqueria Guadalajara, were I Bought a carne asada Burrito and a Torta Sandwich for $14.84. The service was fine, the salsa bar was good. I took the food home and saw that the $7.50 (+ Tax) Burrito was quite thin, even so I enthusiastically bit into my skinny burrito.  Not a good experience. The meat portion was miniscule and the meat itself was rubbery, grisly and excessively SALTY. I was basically served a bean, salt and cilantro  Burrito. The Burrito was so salty and had so much cilantro, that although I was very hungry I was unable to eat it. My friend gave me part of his Torta Sandwich and although better than the burrito, it hardly had any cheese, the sandwich was not cut in half, and the same overly salty, grisly, precooked, rubbery meat was used. Taqueria El Farolito down the street, charges $1.50 less,  $13.23 for a Super Burrito and a Torta, and their Burritos are twice the size of the anorexic  one I received at Taqueria Guadalajara, and the torta sandwiches are so much better, the Tortas sandwiches at EL Farolito are made with a couple of fresh cooked steaks, not with precooked, grisly, rubbery and salty chopped meat.
As for that burrito, I had to throw it away. I have been eating Burritos in the Mission district for 35+ years, and this is the first time I had to throw the food away in quite some years.  I have eaten here before and I  like their habanero salsa.  Their longtime cook Miguel is gone an so has the quality of the food of this taqueria.
Conclusion:  although the service, the salsas and the ambiance were good, presently the food portion is miserly and tastes awful. I like salt, I like cilantro, but their food had way to much of both drowning out all but the salsa and compared to the other Taquerias on 24th street , way too little in the meat department. As of this 2012 writing I plan to eat elsewhere. I was hungry and I had to throw my carne asada burrito away. Cannot recommend.
author: Charlie T.

description: Chips=Doritos and this is never a good sign, especially because they're on 24th St and giving a call to La Palma for a supply of "real" chips shouldn't be so hard. By the way, carne asada in my tacos was cut into small cubes and I don't know if i like it, especially if it's topped with a grayish salsa. Not bad though, but I got scared for two seconds. The quesadilla looked like a burrito, no kidding, and the carnitas was absolutely top quality, no comments, just big chomps. Tell me what you want but the leather seats are tacky.
author: Dario B.

description:
this place seems to be a new addition to the 24th st taqueria fest. n ordered a chile verde burrito 'ranchero' - a unique option involving cheese, salsa, and cilantro. i ordered two tacos - al pastor and carnitas. ALL THREE pork preps were really really good. while the chile verde did not beat out el metate, it's pretty solid. the carnitas and al pastor were both quite amazing. in summary, we believe they have mastered the holy trinity of pork.

let's hope they keep up the good work.

(update 8/31/2007: i've visited this place a couple more times and it still deserves 5 stars. their carnitas is so delicious: crispy on the outside, moist and tender on the inside with lots of flavor. my biggest decision of late has been whether to have it in taco or burrito form. one day, i'll try their shrimp)
author: Angi C.

description: Thank god the removed Mr. Pizza Man and put in this taqueria. I have only gone 2 times but the quesadilla and burrito I had (separate times for both) we up to par. I especially enjoy the atmosphere of this place. Everything is  colorful, there is a mural splashed out on the walls, it's roomier than I can remember when it was Mr. Pizza Man (which I'm reviewing after this), and the service is good too. I originally gave this place 3 stars but changed it to 4 because although they don't serve beer there yet, the lady told me to run across the street to the liquor store and come back. Thats Boss!!
author: James J.

description: This place is awesome. I've not had a single bad meal here and I've tried most of menu.
author: Glenn G.

description:
GOOD. Prices a little high but portions are big. Taste is ok could use a little more spices.
Salsas are good. Horchata is off the hook!
Wet burrito really good and really big. If you order it, that'll be your lunch and dinner.
author: Maria H.

description:
i would recommend this place for their nacho plate alone!
it is HUGE!  and it comes with beans and salsa and cheese and sour cream and big slices of avocado!
it's like heaven on a plate.

i've also had the pleasure of having a chicken taco from here.
this is one hell of a taco.  it's so big i had a hard time wrapping the ends of it together to take a bite out of it.
it, too, came complete with slices of avocado.  i think they have to be one of the things i like the best about it.

i would, and wholeheartedly do, recommend this place for a quick stop taco/burrito/nacho plate.
author: Lily B.

description:
This is definitely my favorite taqueria.  There are no real surprises here, just standard taqueria-style food done better than anybody else.  The beans are great and flavorful and not overcooked.  The meats are all well-seasoned and cooked properly.  The service is quick and attentive.  The setting...leaves something to be desired, but it's a taqueria after all.  The aguas frescas are in general a bit disappointing, but they usually are at most taquerias.  Another plus is that the food is quite consistent.  It's also nice that they accept cards, or I might visit Tonayense across the street a little more often as they are different, and sometimes I'm just in the mood for Tonayense.  

It is far more pleasant than the cafeteria-room feel of Pancho Villa or the insanity of La Taqueria or the homeless passing-through Taqueria Can-Cun.  I still prefer Guadalajara's food even though I would rate them all at about three stars.  They are all different, but ultimately, not that different.  The slight edge on the food and the habanero salsa (insanely hot, perfect for my masochistic taste), keep me coming back here over all the rest.
author: Chris F.

description:
shrimp shrimp shrimp
1.shrimp fajitas
2.shrimp enchiladas
3.shrimp taco
seriously. this is the spot with the fat shrimps. soooooo gooooood.
seems that the gangsters have been swept away from this corner for the time being so head over and get fat.
author: schitzen h.

description: A taqueria with a pleasant sit down feeling.  Their chicken tacos are the bomb.  My gf got their chicken burritos two days in a row.  I will keep the blogosphere updated if she goes a third straight day!
author: Tim G.

description:
I found this place by accident and ordered me a super carnitas burrito with a large horchata. Keep nasty chips! Seriously, going to a taco joint for the chips is like going to a steakhouse for the chicken. But I digress...

Oh... My...God... the burrito was AWESOME. As in 1-800-DELISHUS good.

So needless to say I've gone back there several times for the same thing.

Well today I thought I'd be different and ordered the super pollo asado burrito. It arrived, I bit into it, and tears started flowing down my cheeks.

Tears of utter, unabashed joy. Words fail me to try to describe how otherworldly yummilicious that burrito was... especially when I drizzled Tapatio sauce on it at every bite.

This place is my favorite burrito joint on the face of this Earth and that is no exaggeration. The food is that good and the service is always friendly to a fault. mm mm Mm Mm MMMMMM!!!!!
author: Anthony H.

description: Big, I mean really big, well wrapped pastor burrito with a good ratio of rice, beans, meat, avocado and salsa that is nicely blended for a complex flavor in every bite.  Taqueria Guadalajara has a great atmosphere and cool look, not crowded and the staff is friendly enough.  I'll be back.
author: Thomas T.

description: This was my first time eating at this establishment. The food was prepared nicely and had great flavor.  The Salsa bar had a wide array of different salsas from mild to flaming hot (habanero salsa). I to agree with Fred C. comment of the lack of ice tea and the gristle in the meat.  But in the end it was very tasteful and authentic.  I would recommend this place to my fellow friends & visit it again.
author: Robbie M.

description: I like this place for it's relatively inexpensive menu and homey decor.  The options aren't that much different from your typical Mission taqueria.  However, the portions are fairly large when ordering a full plate dinner or quesadilla.  With $6 you can almost feed 2 folks.  Being the new taqueria on the block among many others, it's faired well.  I visit when I can.
author: Adrian N.

description: Had a wet burrito last night. It was pretty good. There was a lot of meat and not a lot of filler...so I thought. There was a bit too much rice towards the end. When you walk in, the opposite wall to the counter has 2 doors. One of which is painted over as part of the full wall mural. Anyway, they have the usual suspects on their menu and they also highlight a super shrimp burrito ($9.25). I did not get it, but I think should have. Instead I got the wet burrito ($7.25) which was no slouch. The washroom was clean enough and safe to use, even for you ladies. Anyway, for a late night snack, this place is all good.
author: Andrew Y.

description: Carne asada burrito and the carnitas tacos get two thumbs up.  Each.  This is good stuff.
author: Andrew L.

description: Burritos as big as your head.  Some of the better salsa fresca in the Mish.  THE BEST PASTOR.
author: Gianpaolo P.

description: Good chicken quesadilla actually...really yummy! The seats are a little weird but overall the ambiance is pretty neat. Their chips are bad though, I wish they'd make them fresh. Good aguas frescas too!
author: Gina R.

description: Nice place to have a half sit-down, half-fast food lunch break.  They are super friendly, and didn't reprimand me on my weak spanish.  I had two regular tacos with extra jalepenos, and they were tasty.   But, as many have already posted, their chips taste like something out of a Walmart in Nebraska.  That nearly ruined it for me (the chips are the first impression in a mexican place...way important!) and is totally confusing.  They obviously have fresh tortillas...so why not make fresh chips out  of them?  The salsas were good, in fact, everything was pretty good except those tostito/dorito style chips.  Maybe it was just a busy day and they were out of good chips...we'll see.
author: Alexander T.

description: I've only ever had their Ranchero Burrito, and can't comment on anything else.  It rocked my face and I highly recommend it.
author: cindy p.

description:
you must have the carnitas tacos. they take the pork and deep fry it til it's nice and crisp and oh so good. i ordered a burrito with carnitas but they used a different pork, so i guess only the tacos and the tortas come with the deep fried pork. 

not the best atmosphere, and there are some flies that tend to hoover the dining area, but it's fairly clean. they have good pico de gallo that you can help yourself to at the salsa bar. 

good for a cheap and easy meal.
author: Pumakat K.

description:
The best taqueria or best burrito is often the source of heated debates among friends. I have a few friends that swear by this place, but I beg to differ... especially after my experience a few nights ago. 

My friend ordered her burrito wet, the sauce was like a watered down, sweet, class-C enchilada sauce. She had to ask for a second tortilla to empty the contents of the first burrito into. Besides the wet sauce, the burritos are ok, nothing special but edible. The chips are not too great either but they're free so, ok. 

To their credit, the green avocado salsa is pretty good. 

So, the place is ok. Just don't order your burrito wet, you've been warned.
author: Jasmine W.

description: Clean, super fast service and most importantly delicious tacos. I am a fan of cilantro and the boys of Guadalajara use this amazing spice to my delight.
author: Annalies H.

description:
whatever you do, get the shrimp!

shrimp super taco, shrimp quesadilla (my personal fav), shrimp burrito, whatever!  just get some shrimps!!  

add this to the green salsa, the extra salty chips, the loud mariachi music  the crazy mexican tv playing on 2 giant flat screen tv's, and the equally crazy line cook screaming "aniMALL!!" along with all sorts of jungle noises, and i'm in taqueria heaven!!

did i mention that you should get the shimp?

oh yeah, and open till 1am!!
author: Spatial K.

description:
OK. So i've lived right around the corner from this place for three years, like when it used to be the most disgusting mr. pizza man (owner was an creepy ASSHOLE by the way and was arrested for who knows what.) Ugh. But I was bummed to see yet another taqueria. I wanted better pizza or something. anyway.

When I first went in here, they took forever and then gave me a slop taco of only beans when I asked for a bean taco. ew. second time, they forgot my order and i waited over a half hour for a taco. wtf? i give up.

so months go by and it's late after some drinkys (**open LATE. I think 2am? fuck yeah!**) so i want a taco. I go in for the most heavenly veggie taco EVER. It's the best veggie taco I've had in the city I think. seriously! Chips could be better. But this place rules. So they had a slow start? Whatevs. I'm hooked now. and stokey i live around the corner. yep yep.

oh and the green salsa is yummmmmy too. never had the shrimp, but I'm a shrimp junkie, so i'm there for it tonight!
author: Burleigh Girl G.

description: I LOVE this taqueria. I've been working in the area, and keep meaning to bring lunch with me to save money but i cannot resist this place. The tacos are beautiful! Carnitas is my favorite - no steak - no I can't decide!
author: Richie S.

description:
Great great great mexican food

The gf and I usually stop here on our way back to my house from the BART station. Great tacos, great burritos, great quesadillas, great price. 

My only realy complaint is that they give you too much food.

It's my alternative to Pancho Villa when I'm in the 24th St. area of the Mission.
author: Andrew B.

description:
I live next door to this place, and I keep wanting to broaden my horizons, but I just keep coming back for the amazing Super Taco. Their ever-changing salsa bar is great, although the chips (I'll agree with others) are disappointing.

Last week I made myself go to everyone's favorite, la Taqueria on Mission near 25th, and I got an equivalent taco--for nearly twice the money.
author: James W.

description: its not the best burrito in the city but if you're just comin out from a night at the bars you wont go home unsatisfied. the service is good and you get your food pretty quickly. i really dig the atmosphere in the place. they got the whole mexican village thing on the walls which adds a bit of spice to the place.
author: Andrew D.

description: baah.  not very good.  the enchilada sauce tasted like it was made with ketchup.
author: eric i.

description: during my walk down burrito lane, i ducked in here to try it out.  the bad: the chips!  why oh why don't they make their own?  ick!!  the good: the salsas, fresh, spricy, couldn't get enough (also makes the chips that much more shameful).  the burrito: wonderfully grilled tortilla, great grilled chicken, could have used a little more avocado, otherwise deliciouso!
author: e w.

description: competent but nothing special burritos.  best salsa bar on 24th street though, hand's down.
author: Mike E.

description: look. i'm from texas, and my standards for mexican food are off the heezy. this place is as good as my second favorite place in houston, and that says alot. all i have to say is,GET THE SUPER NACHOS WITH PORK! pork rules. and here, they treat it with respect and dignity. it's well priced, and never crowded like el farolito is. so, you can avoid running into drunken idiots.
author: michelle b.
